She could\r\n\r\n      not hide the fact that she had been struck on the head, and yet that wound\r\n\r\n      appeared evidently to have been inflicted during the first phase, since it\r\n\r\n      required the presence of the murderer! I thought Mademoiselle Stangerson\r\n\r\n      had hidden the wound by arranging her hair in bands on her forehead.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAs to the mark of the hand on the wall, that had evidently been made\r\n\r\n      during the first phase\u2014when the murderer was really there. All the\r\n\r\n      traces of his presence had naturally been left during the first phase; the\r\n\r\n      mutton-bone, the black footprints, the Basque cap, the handkerchief, the\r\n\r\n      blood on the wall, on the door, and on the floor. If those traces were\r\n\r\n      still all there, they showed that Mademoiselle Stangerson\u2014who\r\n\r\n      desired that nothing should be known\u2014had not yet had time to clear\r\n\r\n      them away. This led me to the conclusion that the two phases had taken\r\n\r\n      place one shortly after the other. She had not had the opportunity, after\r\n\r\n      leaving her room and going back to the laboratory to her father, to get\r\n\r\n      back again to her room and put it in order. Her father was all the time\r\n\r\n      with her, working. So that after the first phase she did not re-enter her\r\n\r\n      chamber till midnight. Daddy Jacques was there at ten o\u2019clock, as he was\r\n\r\n      every night; but he went in merely to close the blinds and light the\r\n\r\n      night-light. Owing to her disturbed state of mind she had forgotten that\r\n\r\n      Daddy Jacques would go into her room and had begged him not to trouble\r\n\r\n      himself. All this was set forth in the article in the \u2018Matin.\u2019 Daddy\r\n\r\n      Jacques did go, however, and, in the dim light of the room, saw nothing.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMademoiselle Stangerson must have lived some anxious moments while Daddy\r\n\r\n      Jacques was absent; but I think she was not aware that so many evidences\r\n\r\n      had been left. After she had been attacked she had only time to hide the\r\n\r\n      traces of the man\u2019s fingers on her neck and to hurry to the laboratory.\r\n\r\n      Had she known of the bone, the cap, and the handkerchief, she would have\r\n\r\n      made away with them after she had gone back to her chamber at midnight.\r\n\r\n      She did not see them, and undressed by the uncertain glimmer of the night\r\n\r\n      light. She went to bed, worn-out by anxiety and fear\u2014a fear that had\r\n\r\n      made her remain in the laboratory as late as possible.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMy reasoning had thus brought me to the second phase of the tragedy, when\r\n\r\n      Mademoiselle Stangerson was alone in the room. I had now to explain the\r\n\r\n      revolver shots fired during the second phase. Cries of \u2018Help!\u2014Murder!\u2019\r\n\r\n      had been heard. How to explain these? As to the cries, I was in no\r\n\r\n      difficulty; since she was alone in her room these could result from\r\n\r\n      nightmare only. My explanation of the struggle and noise that were heard\r\n\r\n      is simply that in her nightmare she was haunted by the terrible experience\r\n\r\n      she had passed through in the afternoon. In her dream she sees the\r\n\r\n      murderer about to spring upon her and she cries, \u2018Help! Murder!\u2019 Her hand\r\n\r\n      wildly seeks the revolver she had placed within her reach on the\r\n\r\n      night-table by the side of her bed, but her hand, striking the table,\r\n\r\n      overturns it, and the revolver, falling to the floor, discharges itself,\r\n\r\n      the bullet lodging in the ceiling. I knew from the first that the bullet\r\n\r\n      in the ceiling must have resulted from an accident. Its very position\r\n\r\n      suggested an accident to my mind, and so fell in with my theory of a\r\n\r\n      nightmare. I no longer doubted that the attack had taken place before\r\n\r\n      Mademoiselle had retired for the night. After wakening from her frightful\r\n\r\n      dream and crying aloud for help, she had fainted.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMy theory, based on the evidence of the shots that were heard at\r\n\r\n      midnight, demanded two shots\u2014one which wounded the murderer at the\r\n\r\n      time of his attack, and one fired at the time of the nightmare. The\r\n\r\n      evidence given by the Berniers before the examining magistrate was to the\r\n\r\n      effect that only one shot had been heard. Monsieur Stangerson testified to\r\n\r\n      hearing a dull sound first followed by a sharp ringing sound. The dull\r\n\r\n      sound I explained by the falling of the marble-topped table; the ringing\r\n\r\n      sound was the shot from the revolver. I was now convinced I was right. The\r\n\r\n      shot that had wounded the hand of the murderer and had caused it to bleed\r\n\r\n      so that he left the bloody imprint on the wall was fired by Mademoiselle\r\n\r\n      in self-defence, before the second phase, when she had been really\r\n\r\n      attacked. The shot in the ceiling which the Berniers heard was the\r\n\r\n      accidental shot during the nightmare.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI had now to explain the wound on the temple. It was not severe enough to\r\n\r\n      have been made by means of the mutton-bone, and Mademoiselle had not\r\n\r\n      attempted to hide it. It must have been made during the second phase. It\r\n\r\n      was to find this out that I went to \u201cThe Yellow Room\u201d, and I obtained my\r\n\r\n      answer there.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille drew a piece of white folded paper from his pocket, and drew\r\n\r\n      out of it an almost invisible object which he held between his thumb and\r\n\r\n      forefinger.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThis, Monsieur President,\u201d he said, \u201cis a hair\u2014a blond hair stained\r\n\r\n      with blood;\u2014it is a hair from the head of Mademoiselle Stangerson. I\r\n\r\n      found it sticking to one of the corners of the overturned table. The\r\n\r\n      corner of the table was itself stained with blood\u2014a tiny stain\u2014hardly\r\n\r\n      visible; but it told me that, on rising from her bed, Mademoiselle\r\n\r\n      Stangerson had fallen heavily and had struck her head on the corner of its\r\n\r\n      marble top.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI still had to learn, in addition to the name of the assassin, which I\r\n\r\n      did later, the time of the original attack. I learned this from the\r\n\r\n      examination of Mademoiselle Stangerson and her father, though the answers\r\n\r\n      given by the former were well calculated to deceive the examining\r\n\r\n      magistrate\u2014Mademoiselle Stangerson had stated very minutely how she\r\n\r\n      had spent the whole of her time that day. We established the fact that the\r\n\r\n      murderer had introduced himself into the pavilion between five and six\r\n\r\n      o\u2019clock. At a quarter past six the professor and his daughter had resumed\r\n\r\n      their work. At five the professor had been with his daughter, and since\r\n\r\n      the attack took place in the professor\u2019s absence from his daughter, I had\r\n\r\n      to find out just when he left her. The professor had stated that at the\r\n\r\n      time when he and his daughter were about to re-enter the laboratory he was\r\n\r\n      met by the keeper and held in conversation about the cutting of some wood\r\n\r\n      and the poachers. Mademoiselle Stangerson was not with him then since the\r\n\r\n      professor said: \u2018I left the keeper and rejoined my daughter who was at\r\n\r\n      work in the laboratory.\u2019\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cIt was during that short interval of time that the tragedy took place.\r\n\r\n      That is certain. In my mind\u2019s eye I saw Mademoiselle Stangerson re-enter\r\n\r\n      the pavilion, go to her room to take off her hat, and find herself faced\r\n\r\n      by the murderer. He had been in the pavilion for some time waiting for\r\n\r\n      her. He had arranged to pass the whole night there. He had taken off Daddy\r\n\r\n      Jacques\u2019s boots; he had removed the papers from the cabinet; and had then\r\n\r\n      slipped under the bed. Finding the time long, he had risen, gone again\r\n\r\n      into the laboratory, then into the vestibule, looked into the garden, and\r\n\r\n      had seen, coming towards the pavilion, Mademoiselle Stangerson\u2014alone.\r\n\r\n      He would never have dared to attack her at that hour, if he had not found\r\n\r\n      her alone. His mind was made up. He would be more at ease alone with\r\n\r\n      Mademoiselle Stangerson in the pavilion, than he would have been in the\r\n\r\n      middle of the night, with Daddy Jacques sleeping in the attic. So he shut\r\n\r\n      the vestibule window. That explains why neither Monsieur Stangerson, nor\r\n\r\n      the keeper, who were at some distance from the pavilion, had heard the\r\n\r\n      revolver shot.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThen he went back to \u201cThe Yellow Room\u201d. Mademoiselle Stangerson came in.\r\n\r\n      What passed must have taken place very quickly. Mademoiselle tried to call\r\n\r\n      for help; but the man had seized her by the throat. Her hand had sought\r\n\r\n      and grasped the revolver which she had been keeping in the drawer of her\r\n\r\n      night-table, since she had come to fear the threats of her pursuer. The\r\n\r\n      murderer was about to strike her on the head with the mutton-bone\u2014a\r\n\r\n      terrible weapon in the hands of a Larsan or Ballmeyer; but she fired in\r\n\r\n      time, and the shot wounded the hand that held the weapon. The bone fell to\r\n\r\n      the floor covered with the blood of the murderer, who staggered, clutched\r\n\r\n      at the wall for support\u2014imprinting on it the red marks\u2014and,\r\n\r\n      fearing another bullet, fled.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cShe saw him pass through the laboratory, and listened. He was long at the\r\n\r\n      window. At length he jumped from it. She flew to it and shut it. The\r\n\r\n      danger past, all her thoughts were of her father. Had he either seen or\r\n\r\n      heard? At any cost to herself she must keep this from him. Thus when\r\n\r\n      Monsieur Stangerson returned, he found the door of \u201cThe Yellow Room\u201d closed,\r\n\r\n      and his daughter in the laboratory, bending over her desk, at work!\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Turning towards Monsieur Darzac, Rouletabille cried: \u201cYou know the truth!\r\n\r\n      Tell us, then, if that is not how things happened.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI don\u2019t know anything about it,\u201d replied Monsieur Darzac.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI admire you for your silence,\u201d said Rouletabille, \u201cbut if Mademoiselle\r\n\r\n      Stangerson knew of your danger, she would release you from your oath. She\r\n\r\n      would beg of you to tell all she has confided to you. She would be here to\r\n\r\n      defend you!\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Monsieur Darzac made no movement, nor uttered a word. He looked at\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille sadly.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cHowever,\u201d said the young reporter, \u201csince Mademoiselle is not here, I\r\n\r\n      must do it myself. But, believe me, Monsieur Darzac, the only means to\r\n\r\n      save Mademoiselle Stangerson and restore her to her reason, is to secure\r\n\r\n      your acquittal.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWhat is this secret motive that compels Mademoiselle Stangerson to hide\r\n\r\n      her knowledge from her father?\u201d asked the President.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThat, Monsieur, I do not know,\u201d said Rouletabille. \u201cIt is no business of\r\n\r\n      mine.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      The President, turning to Monsieur Darzac, endeavoured to induce him to\r\n\r\n      tell what he knew.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cDo you still refuse, Monsieur, to tell us how you employeed your time\r\n\r\n      during the attempts on the life of Mademoiselle Stangerson?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI cannot tell you anything, Monsieur.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      The President turned to Rouletabille as if appealing for an explanation.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWe must assume, Monsieur President, that Monsieur Robert Darzac\u2019s\r\n\r\n      absences are closely connected with Mademoiselle Stangerson\u2019s secret, and\r\n\r\n      that Monsieur Darzac feels himself in honour bound to remain silent. It\r\n\r\n      may be that Larsan, who, since his three attempts, has had everything in\r\n\r\n      training to cast suspicion on Monsieur Darzac, had fixed on just those\r\n\r\n      occasions for a meeting with Monsieur Darzac at a spot most compromising.\r\n\r\n      Larsan is cunning enough to have done that.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      The President seemed partly convinced, but still curious, he asked:\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBut what is this secret of Mademoiselle Stangerson?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThat I cannot tell you,\u201d said Rouletabille. \u201cI think, however, you know\r\n\r\n      enough now to acquit Monsieur Robert Darzac! Unless Larsan should return,\r\n\r\n      and I don\u2019t think he will,\u201d he added, with a laugh.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cOne question more,\u201d said the President. \u201cAdmitting your explanation, we\r\n\r\n      know that Larsan wished to turn suspicion on Monsieur Robert Darzac, but\r\n\r\n      why should he throw suspicion on Daddy Jacques also?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThere came in the professional detective, Monsieur, who proves himself an\r\n\r\n      unraveller of mysteries, by annihilating the very proofs he had\r\n\r\n      accumulated. He\u2019s a very cunning man, and a similar trick had often\r\n\r\n      enabled him to turn suspicion from himself. He proved the innocence of one\r\n\r\n      before accusing the other. You can easily believe, Monsieur, that so\r\n\r\n      complicated a scheme as this must have been long and carefully thought out\r\n\r\n      in advance by Larsan. I can tell you that he had long been engaged on its\r\n\r\n      elaboration. If you care to learn how he had gathered information, you\r\n\r\n      will find that he had, on one occasion, disguised himself as the\r\n\r\n      commissionaire between the \u2018Laboratory of the Surete\u2019 and Monsieur\r\n\r\n      Stangerson, of whom \u2018experiments\u2019 were demanded. In this way he had been\r\n\r\n      able before the crime, on two occasions to take stock of the pavilion. He\r\n\r\n      had \u2018made up\u2019 so that Daddy Jacques had not recognised him. And yet Larsan\r\n\r\n      had found the opportunity to rob the old man of a pair of old boots and a\r\n\r\n      cast-off Basque cap, which the servant had tied up in a handkerchief, with\r\n\r\n      the intention of carrying them to a friend, a charcoal-burner on the road\r\n\r\n      to Epinay. When the crime was discovered, Daddy Jacques had immediately\r\n\r\n      recognised these objects as his. They were extremely compromising, which\r\n\r\n      explains his distress at the time when we spoke to him about them. Larsan\r\n\r\n      confessed it all to me. He is an artist at the game. He did a similar\r\n\r\n      thing in the affair of the \u2018Credit Universel,\u2019 and in that of the \u2018Gold\r\n\r\n      Ingots of the Mint.\u2019 Both these cases should be revised. Since Ballmeyer\r\n\r\n      or Larsan has been in the Surete a number of innocent persons have been\r\n\r\n      sent to prison.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n \r\n\r\n\r\n      CHAPTER XXVIII. In Which It Is Proved That One Does Not Always Think of\r\n\r\n      Everything\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Great excitement prevailed when Rouletabille had finished. The court-room\r\n\r\n      became agitated with the murmurings of suppressed applause. Maitre Henri\r\n\r\n      Robert called for an adjournment of the trial and was supported in his\r\n\r\n      motion by the public prosecutor himself. The case was adjourned. The next\r\n\r\n      day Monsieur Robert Darzac was released on bail, while Daddy Jacques\r\n\r\n      received the immediate benefit of a \u201cno cause for action.\u201d Search was\r\n\r\n      everywhere made for Frederic Larsan, but in vain. Monsieur Darzac finally\r\n\r\n      escaped the awful calamity which, at one time, had threatened him. After a\r\n\r\n      visit to Mademoiselle Stangerson, he was led to hope that she might, by\r\n\r\n      careful nursing, one day recover her reason.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille, naturally, became the \u201cman of the hour.\u201d On leaving the\r\n\r\n      Palais de Justice, the crowd bore him aloft in triumph. The press of the\r\n\r\n      whole world published his exploits and his photograph. He, who had\r\n\r\n      interviewed so many illustrious personages, had himself become illustrious\r\n\r\n      and was interviewed in his turn. I am glad to say that the enormous\r\n\r\n      success in no way turned his head.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      We left Versailles together, after having dined at \u201cThe Dog That Smokes.\u201d\r\n\r\n       In the train I put a number of questions to him which, during our meal,\r\n\r\n      had been on the tip of my tongue, but which I had refrained from uttering,\r\n\r\n      knowing he did not like to talk \u201cshop\u201d while eating.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMy friend,\u201d I said, \u201cthat Larsan case is wonderful. It is worthy of you.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      He begged me to say no more, and humorously pretended an anxiety for me\r\n\r\n      should I give way to silly praise of him because of a personal admiration\r\n\r\n      for his ability.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI\u2019ll come to the point, then,\u201d I said, not a little nettled. \u201cI am still\r\n\r\n      in the dark as to your reason for going to America. When you left the\r\n\r\n      Glandier you had found out, if I rightly understand, all about Frederic\r\n\r\n      Larsan; you had discovered the exact way he had attempted the murder?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cQuite so. And you,\u201d he said, turning the conversation, \u201cdid you suspect\r\n\r\n      nothing?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cNothing!\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cIt\u2019s incredible!\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI don\u2019t see how I could have suspected anything. You took great pains to\r\n\r\n      conceal your thoughts from me. Had you already suspected Larsan when you\r\n\r\n      sent for me to bring the revolvers?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYes! I had come to that conclusion through the incident of the\r\n\r\n      \u2018inexplicable gallery.\u2019 Larsan\u2019s return to Mademoiselle Stangerson\u2019s room,\r\n\r\n      however, had not then been cleared up by the eye-glasses. My suspicions\r\n\r\n      were the outcome of my reasoning only; and the idea of Larsan being the\r\n\r\n      murderer seemed so extraordinary that I resolved to wait for actual\r\n\r\n      evidence before venturing to act. Nevertheless, the suspicion worried me,\r\n\r\n      and I sometimes spoke to the detective in a way that ought to have opened\r\n\r\n      your eyes. I spoke disparagingly of his methods. But until I found the\r\n\r\n      eye-glasses I could but look upon my suspicion of him in the light of an\r\n\r\n      absurd hypothesis only. You can imagine my elation after I had explained\r\n\r\n      Larsan\u2019s movements. I remember well rushing into my room like a mad-man\r\n\r\n      and crying to you: \u2018I\u2019ll get the better of the great Fred. I\u2019ll get the\r\n\r\n      better of him in a way that will make a sensation!\u2019\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI was then thinking of Larsan, the murderer. It was that same evening\r\n\r\n      that Darzac begged me to watch over Mademoiselle Stangerson. I made no\r\n\r\n      efforts until after we had dined with Larsan, until ten o\u2019clock. He was\r\n\r\n      right there before me, and I could afford to wait. You ought to have\r\n\r\n      suspected, because when we were talking of the murderer\u2019s arrival, I said\r\n\r\n      to you: \u2018I am quite sure Larsan will be here to-night.\u2019\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBut one important point escaped us both. It was one which ought to have\r\n\r\n      opened our eyes to Larsan. Do you remember the bamboo cane? I was\r\n\r\n      surprised to find Larsan had made no use of that evidence against Robert\r\n\r\n      Darzac. Had it not been purchased by a man whose description tallied\r\n\r\n      exactly with that of Darzac? Well, just before I saw him off at the train,\r\n\r\n      after the recess during the trial, I asked him why he hadn\u2019t used the cane\r\n\r\n      evidence. He told me he had never had any intention of doing so; that our\r\n\r\n      discovery of it in the little inn at Epinay had much embarrassed him. If\r\n\r\n      you will remember, he told us then that the cane had been given him in\r\n\r\n      London. Why did we not immediately say to ourselves: \u2018Fred is lying. He\r\n\r\n      could not have had this cane in London. He was not in London. He bought it\r\n\r\n      in Paris\u2019? Then you found out, on inquiry at Cassette\u2019s, that the cane had\r\n\r\n      been bought by a person dressed very like Robert Darzac, though, as we\r\n\r\n      learned later, from Darzac himself, it was not he who had made the\r\n\r\n      purchase. Couple this with the fact we already knew, from the letter at\r\n\r\n      the poste restante, that there was actually a man in Paris who was passing\r\n\r\n      as Robert Darzac, why did we not immediately fix on Fred himself?\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cOf course, his position at the Surete was against us; but when we saw the\r\n\r\n      evident eagerness on his part to find convicting evidence against Darzac,\r\n\r\n      nay, even the passion he displayed in his pursuit of the man, the lie\r\n\r\n      about the cane should have had a new meaning for us. If you ask why Larsan\r\n\r\n      bought the cane, if he had no intention of manufacturing evidence against\r\n\r\n      Darzac by means of it, the answer is quite simple. He had been wounded in\r\n\r\n      the hand by Mademoiselle Stangerson, so that the cane was useful to enable\r\n\r\n      him to close his hand in carrying it. You remember I noticed that he\r\n\r\n      always carried it?\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAll these details came back to my mind when I had once fixed on Larsan as\r\n\r\n      the criminal. But they were too late then to be of any use to me. On the\r\n\r\n      evening when he pretended to be drugged I looked at his hand and saw a\r\n\r\n      thin silk bandage covering the signs of a slight healing wound. Had we\r\n\r\n      taken a quicker initiative at the time Larsan told us that lie about the\r\n\r\n      cane, I am certain he would have gone off, to avoid suspicion. All the\r\n\r\n      same, we worried Larsan or Ballmeyer without our knowing it.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBut,\u201d I interrupted, \u201cif Larsan had no intention of using the cane as\r\n\r\n      evidence against Darzac, why had he made himself up to look like the man\r\n\r\n      when he went in to buy it?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cHe had not specially \u2018made up\u2019 as Darzac to buy the cane; he had come\r\n\r\n      straight to Cassette\u2019s immediately after he had attacked Mademoiselle\r\n\r\n      Stangerson. His wound was troubling him and, as he was passing along the\r\n\r\n      Avenue de l\u2019Opera, the idea of the cane came to his mind and he acted on\r\n\r\n      it. It was then eight o\u2019clock. And I, who had hit upon the very hour of\r\n\r\n      the occurrence of the tragedy, almost convinced that Darzac was not the\r\n\r\n      criminal, and knowing of the cane, I still never suspected Larsan. There\r\n\r\n      are times...\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThere are times,\u201d I said, \u201cwhen the greatest intellects\u2014...\u201d\r\n\r\n       Rouletabille shut my mouth. I still continued to chide him, but, finding\r\n\r\n      he did not reply, I saw he was no longer paying any attention to what I\r\n\r\n      was saying. I found he was fast asleep.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n \r\n\r\n\r\n      CHAPTER XXIX. The Mystery of Mademoiselle Stangerson\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      During the days that followed I had several opportunities to question him\r\n\r\n      as to his reason for his voyage to America, but I obtained no more precise\r\n\r\n      answers than he had given me on the evening of the adjournment of the\r\n\r\n      trial, when we were on the train for Paris. One day, however, on my still\r\n\r\n      pressing him, he said:\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cCan\u2019t you understand that I had to know Larsan\u2019s true personality?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cNo doubt,\u201d I said, \u201cbut why did you go to America to find that out?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      He sat smoking his pipe, and made no further reply. I began to see that I\r\n\r\n      was touching on the secret that concerned Mademoiselle Stangerson.\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille evidently had found it necessary to go to America to find out\r\n\r\n      what the mysterious tie was that bound her to Larsan by so strange and\r\n\r\n      terrible a bond. In America he had learned who Larsan was and had obtained\r\n\r\n      information which closed his mouth. He had been to Philadelphia.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      And now, what was this mystery which held Mademoiselle Stangerson and\r\n\r\n      Monsieur Robert Darzac in so inexplicable a silence? After so many years\r\n\r\n      and the publicity given the case by a curious and shameless press; now\r\n\r\n      that Monsieur Stangerson knows all and has forgiven all, all may be told.\r\n\r\n      In every phase of this remarkable story Mademoiselle Stangerson had always\r\n\r\n      been the sufferer.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      The beginning dates from the time when, as a young girl, she was living\r\n\r\n      with her father in Philadelphia. A visitor at the house, a Frenchman, had\r\n\r\n      succeeded by his wit, grace and persistent attention, in gaining her\r\n\r\n      affections. He was said to be rich and had asked her of her father.\r\n\r\n      Monsieur Stangerson, on making inquiries as to Monsieur Jean Roussel,\r\n\r\n      found that the man was a swindler and an adventurer. Jean Roussel was but\r\n\r\n      another of the many names under which the notorious Ballmeyer, a fugitive\r\n\r\n      from France, tried to hide himself. Monsieur Stangerson did not know of\r\n\r\n      his identity with Ballmeyer; he learned that the man was simply\r\n\r\n      undesirable for his daughter. He not only refused to give his consent to\r\n\r\n      the marriage but denied him admission into the house. Mathilde Stangerson,\r\n\r\n      however, had fallen in love. To her Jean Roussel was everything that her\r\n\r\n      love painted him. She was indignant at her father\u2019s attitude, and did not\r\n\r\n      conceal her feelings. Her father sent her to stay with an aunt in\r\n\r\n      Cincinnati. There she was joined by Jean Roussel and, in spite of the\r\n\r\n      reverence she felt for her father, ran away with him to get married.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      They went to Louisville and lived there for some time. One morning,\r\n\r\n      however, a knock came at the door of the house in which they were and the\r\n\r\n      police entered to arrest Jean Roussel. It was then that Mathilde\r\n\r\n      Stangerson, or Roussel, learned that her husband was no other than the\r\n\r\n      notorious Ballmeyer!\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      The young woman in her despair tried to commit suicide. She failed in\r\n\r\n      this, and was forced to rejoin her aunt in Cincinnati, The old lady was\r\n\r\n      overjoyed to see her again. She had been anxiously searching for her and\r\n\r\n      had not dared to tell Monsieur Stangerson of her disappearance. Mathilde\r\n\r\n      swore her to secrecy, so that her father should not know she had been\r\n\r\n      away. A month later, Mademoiselle Stangerson returned to her father,\r\n\r\n      repentant, her heart dead within her, hoping only one thing: that she\r\n\r\n      would never again see her husband, the horrible Ballmeyer. A report was\r\n\r\n      spread, a few weeks later, that he was dead, and she now determined to\r\n\r\n      atone for her disobedience by a life of labour and devotion for her\r\n\r\n      father. And she kept her word.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      All this she had confessed to Robert Darzac, and, believing Ballmeyer\r\n\r\n      dead, had given herself to the joy of a union with him. But fate had\r\n\r\n      resuscitated Jean Roussel\u2014the Ballmeyer of her youth. He had taken\r\n\r\n      steps to let her know that he would never allow her to marry Darzac\u2014that\r\n\r\n      he still loved her.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Mademoiselle Stangerson never for one moment hesitated to confide in\r\n\r\n      Monsieur Darzac. She showed him the letter in which Jean Roussel asked her\r\n\r\n      to recall the first hours of their union in their beautiful and charming\r\n\r\n      Louisville home. \u201cThe presbytery has lost nothing of its charm, nor the\r\n\r\n      garden its brightness,\u201d he had written. The scoundrel pretended to be rich\r\n\r\n      and claimed the right of taking her back to Louisville. She had told\r\n\r\n      Darzac that if her father should know of her dishonour, she would kill\r\n\r\n      herself. Monsieur Darzac had sworn to silence her persecutor, even if he\r\n\r\n      had to kill him. He was outwitted and would have succumbed had it not been\r\n\r\n      for the genius of Rouletabille.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Mademoiselle Stangerson was herself helpless in the hands of such a\r\n\r\n      villain. She had tried to kill him when he had first threatened and then\r\n\r\n      attacked her in \u201cThe Yellow Room\u201d. She had, unfortunately, failed, and felt\r\n\r\n      herself condemned to be for ever at the mercy of this unscrupulous wretch\r\n\r\n      who was continually demanding her presence at clandestine interviews. When\r\n\r\n      he sent her the letter through the Post Office, asking her to meet him,\r\n\r\n      she had refused. The result of her refusal was the tragedy of The Yellow\r\n\r\n      Room. The second time he wrote asking for a meeting, the letter reaching\r\n\r\n      her in her sick chamber, she had avoided him by sleeping with her\r\n\r\n      servants. In that letter the scoundrel had warned her that, since she was\r\n\r\n      too ill to come to him, he would come to her, and that he would be in her\r\n\r\n      chamber at a particular hour on a particular night. Knowing that she had\r\n\r\n      everything to fear from Ballmeyer, she had left her chamber on that night.\r\n\r\n      It was then that the incident of the \u201cinexplicable gallery\u201d occurred.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      The third time she had determined to keep the appointment. He asked for it\r\n\r\n      in the letter he had written in her own room, on the night of the incident\r\n\r\n      in the gallery, which he left on her desk. In that letter he threatened to\r\n\r\n      burn her father\u2019s papers if she did not meet him. It was to rescue these\r\n\r\n      papers that she made up her mind to see him. She did not for one moment\r\n\r\n      doubt that the wretch would carry out his threat if she persisted in\r\n\r\n      avoiding him, and in that case the labours of her father\u2019s lifetime would\r\n\r\n      be for ever lost. Since the meeting was thus inevitable, she resolved to\r\n\r\n      see her husband and appeal to his better nature. It was for this interview\r\n\r\n      that she had prepared herself on the night the keeper was killed. They did\r\n\r\n      meet, and what passed between them may be imagined. He insisted that she\r\n\r\n      renounce Darzac. She, on her part, affirmed her love for him. He stabbed\r\n\r\n      her in his anger, determined to convict Darzac of the crime. As Larsan he\r\n\r\n      could do it, and had so managed things that Darzac could never explain how\r\n\r\n      he had employeed the time of his absence from the chateau. Ballmeyer\u2019s\r\n\r\n      precautions were most cunningly taken.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Larsan had threatened Darzac as he had threatened Mathilde\u2014with the\r\n\r\n      same weapon, and the same threats. He wrote Darzac urgent letters,\r\n\r\n      declaring himself ready to deliver up the letters that had passed between\r\n\r\n      him and his wife, and to leave them for ever, if he would pay him his\r\n\r\n      price. He asked Darzac to meet him for the purpose of arranging the\r\n\r\n      matter, appointing the time when Larsan would be with Mademoiselle\r\n\r\n      Stangerson. When Darzac went to Epinay, expecting to find Ballmeyer or\r\n\r\n      Larsan there, he was met by an accomplice of Larsan\u2019s, and kept waiting\r\n\r\n      until such time as the \u201ccoincidence\u201d could be established.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      It was all done with Machiavellian cunning; but Ballmeyer had reckoned\r\n\r\n      without Joseph Rouletabille.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Now that the Mystery of \u201cThe Yellow Room\u201d has been cleared up, this is not\r\n\r\n      the time to tell of Rouletabille\u2019s adventures in America. Knowing the\r\n\r\n      young reporter as we do, we can understand with what acumen he had traced,\r\n\r\n      step by step, the story of Mathilde Stangerson and Jean Roussel. At\r\n\r\n      Philadelphia he had quickly informed himself as to Arthur William Rance.\r\n\r\n      There he learned of Rance\u2019s act of devotion and the reward he thought\r\n\r\n      himself entitled to for it. A rumour of his marriage with Mademoiselle\r\n\r\n      Stangerson had once found its way into the drawing-rooms of Philadelphia.\r\n\r\n      He also learned of Rance\u2019s continued attentions to her and his\r\n\r\n      importunities for her hand. He had taken to drink, he had said, to drown\r\n\r\n      his grief at his unrequited love. It can now be understood why\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille had shown so marked a coolness of demeanour towards Rance\r\n\r\n      when they met in the witnesses\u2019 room, on the day of the trial.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      The strange Roussel-Stangerson mystery had now been laid bare. Who was\r\n\r\n      this Jean Roussel? Rouletabille had traced him from Philadelphia to\r\n\r\n      Cincinnati. In Cincinnati he became acquainted with the old aunt, and had\r\n\r\n      found means to open her mouth. The story of Ballmeyer\u2019s arrest threw the\r\n\r\n      right light on the whole story. He visited the \u201cpresbytery\u201d\u2014a small\r\n\r\n      and pretty dwelling in the old colonial style\u2014which had, indeed,\r\n\r\n      \u201clost nothing of its charm.\u201d Then, abandoning his pursuit of traces of\r\n\r\n      Mademoiselle Stangerson, he took up those of Ballmeyer. He followed them\r\n\r\n      from prison to prison, from crime to crime. Finally, as he was about\r\n\r\n      leaving for Europe, he learned in New York that Ballmeyer had, five years\r\n\r\n      before, embarked for France with some valuable papers belonging to a\r\n\r\n      merchant of New Orleans whom he had murdered.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      And yet the whole of this mystery has not been revealed. Mademoiselle\r\n\r\n      Stangerson had a child, by her husband,\u2014a son. The infant was born\r\n\r\n      in the old aunt\u2019s house. No one knew of it, so well had the aunt managed\r\n\r\n      to conceal the event.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      What became of that son?\u2014That is another story which, so far, I am\r\n\r\n      not permitted to relate.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      About two months after these events, I came upon Rouletabille sitting on a\r\n\r\n      bench in the Palais de Justice, looking very depressed.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWhat\u2019s the matter, old man?\u201d I asked. \u201cYou are looking very downcast.\r\n\r\n      How are your friends getting on?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cApart from you,\u201d he said, \u201cI have no friends.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI hope that Monsieur Darzac\u2014\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cNo doubt.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAnd Mademoiselle Stangerson\u2014How is she?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBetter\u2014much better.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThen you ought not to be sad.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI am sad,\u201d he said, \u201cbecause I am thinking of the perfume of the lady in\r\n\r\n      black\u2014\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThe perfume of the lady in black!\u2014I have heard you often refer to\r\n\r\n      it. Tell me why it troubles you.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cPerhaps\u2014some day; some day,\u201d said Rouletabille.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      And he heaved a profound sigh.
THE SECRET OF THE NIGHT\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      By Gaston Leroux\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n \r\n\r\n\r\n \r\n\r\n\r\nCONTENTS\r\n\r\n\r\n  THE SECRET OF THE NIGHT\r\n    I. \u00a0\u00a0GAYETY\r\n\r\n        AND DYNAMITE   II. \u00a0\u00a0NATACHA\r\n\r\n          III. \u00a0\u00a0THE WATCH\r\n\r\n          IV. \u00a0\u00a0\"THE YOUTH OF\r\n\r\n        MOSCOW IS DEAD\u201d   V. \u00a0\u00a0BY\r\n\r\n        ROULETABILLE\u2019S ORDER THE GENERAL PROMENADES   VI. \u00a0\u00a0THE MYSTERIOUS HAND \r\n VII. \u00a0\u00a0ARSENATE OF SODA \r\n VIII. \u00a0\u00a0THE LITTLE CHAPEL OF THE\r\n\r\n        GUARDS   IX. \u00a0\u00a0ANNOUCHKA\r\n\r\n          X. \u00a0\u00a0A DRAMA IN THE\r\n\r\n        NIGHT   XI. \u00a0\u00a0THE\r\n\r\n        POISON CONTINUES   XII. \u00a0\u00a0PERE\r\n\r\n        ALEXIS   XIII. \u00a0\u00a0THE\r\n\r\n        LIVING BOMBS   XIV. \u00a0\u00a0THE\r\n\r\n        MARSHES   XV. \u00a0\u00a0\"I HAVE\r\n\r\n        BEEN WAITING FOR YOU\u201d   XVI. \u00a0\u00a0BEFORE\r\n\r\n        THE REVOLUTIONARY TRIBUNAL   XVII.\r\n\r\n        \u00a0\u00a0THE LAST CRAVAT  \r\n\r\n        XVIII. \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0A SINGULAR EXPERIENCE \r\n XIX. \u00a0\u00a0THE TSAR \r\n\r\n\r\n \r\n\r\n\r\n  \r\n \r\n\r\n\r\n      THE SECRET OF THE NIGHT\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n \r\n\r\n\r\n      I. GAYETY AND DYNAMITE\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBARINIA, the young stranger has arrived.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWhere is he?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cOh, he is waiting at the lodge.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI told you to show him to Natacha\u2019s sitting-room. Didn\u2019t you understand\r\n\r\n      me, Ermolai?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cPardon, Barinia, but the young stranger, when I asked to search him, as\r\n\r\n      you directed, flatly refused to let me.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cDid you explain to him that everybody is searched before being allowed to\r\n\r\n      enter, that it is the order, and that even my mother herself has submitted\r\n\r\n      to it?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI told him all that, Barinia; and I told him about madame your mother.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWhat did he say to that?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThat he was not madame your mother. He acted angry.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWell, let him come in without being searched.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThe Chief of Police won\u2019t like it.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cDo as I say.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Ermolai bowed and returned to the garden. The \u201cbarinia\u201d left the veranda,\r\n\r\n      where she had come for this conversation with the old servant of General\r\n\r\n      Trebassof, her husband, and returned to the dining-room in the datcha des\r\n\r\n      Iles, where the gay Councilor Ivan Petrovitch was regaling his amused\r\n\r\n      associates with his latest exploit at Cubat\u2019s resort. They were a noisy\r\n\r\n      company, and certainly the quietest among them was not the general, who\r\n\r\n      nursed on a sofa the leg which still held him captive after the recent\r\n\r\n      attack, that to his old coachman and his two piebald horses had proved\r\n\r\n      fatal. The story of the always-amiable Ivan Petrovitch (a lively, little,\r\n\r\n      elderly man with his head bald as an egg) was about the evening before.\r\n\r\n      After having, as he said, \u201crecure la bouche\u201d for these gentlemen spoke\r\n\r\n      French like their own language and used it among themselves to keep their\r\n\r\n      servants from understanding\u2014after having wet his whistle with a\r\n\r\n      large glass of sparkling rosy French wine, he cried:\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYou would have laughed, Feodor Feodorovitch. We had sung songs on the\r\n\r\n      Barque* and then the Bohemians left with their music and we went out onto\r\n\r\n      the river-bank to stretch our legs and cool our faces in the freshness of\r\n\r\n      the dawn, when a company of Cossacks of the Guard came along. I knew the\r\n\r\n      officer in command and invited him to come along with us and drink the\r\n\r\n      Emperor\u2019s health at Cubat\u2019s place. That officer, Feodor Feodorovitch, is a\r\n\r\n      man who knows vintages and boasts that he has never swallowed a glass of\r\n\r\n      anything so common as Crimean wine. When I named champagne he cried, \u2018Vive\r\n\r\n      l\u2019Empereur!\u2019 A true patriot. So we started, merry as school-children. The\r\n\r\n      entire company followed, then all the diners playing little whistles, and\r\n\r\n      all the servants besides, single file. At Cubat\u2019s I hated to leave the\r\n\r\n      companion-officers of my friend at the door, so I invited them in, too.\r\n\r\n      They accepted, naturally. But the subalterns were thirsty as well. I\r\n\r\n      understand discipline. You know, Feodor Feodorovitch, that I am a stickler\r\n\r\n      for discipline. Just because one is gay of a spring morning, discipline\r\n\r\n      should not be forgotten. I invited the officers to drink in a private\r\n\r\n      room, and sent the subalterns into the main hall of the restaurant. Then\r\n\r\n      the soldiers were thirsty, too, and I had drinks served to them out in the\r\n\r\n      courtyard. Then, my word, there was a perplexing business, for now the\r\n\r\n      horses whinnied. The brave horses, Feodor Feodorovitch, who also wished to\r\n\r\n      drink the health of the Emperor. I was bothered about the discipline.\r\n\r\n      Hall, court, all were full. And I could not put the horses in private\r\n\r\n      rooms. Well, I made them carry out champagne in pails and then came the\r\n\r\n      perplexing business I had tried so hard to avoid, a grand mixture of boots\r\n\r\n      and horse-shoes that was certainly the liveliest thing I have ever seen in\r\n\r\n      my life. But the horses were the most joyous, and danced as if a torch was\r\n\r\n      held under their nostrils, and all of them, my word! were ready to throw\r\n\r\n      their riders because the men were not of the same mind with them as to the\r\n\r\n      route to follow! From our window we laughed fit to kill at such a mixture\r\n\r\n      of sprawling boots and dancing hoofs. But the troopers finally got all\r\n\r\n      their horses to barracks, with patience, for the Emperor\u2019s cavalry are the\r\n\r\n      best riders in the world, Feodor Feodorovitch. And we certainly had a\r\n\r\n      great laugh!\u2014Your health, Matrena Petrovna.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      These last graceful words were addressed to Madame Trebassof, who shrugged\r\n\r\n      her shoulders at the undesired gallantry of the gay Councilor. She did not\r\n\r\n      join in the conversation, excepting to calm the general, who wished to\r\n\r\n      send the whole regiment to the guard-house, men and horses. And while the\r\n\r\n      roisterers laughed over the adventure she said to her husband in the\r\n\r\n      advisory voice of the helpful wife:\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cFeodor, you must not attach importance to what that old fool Ivan tells\r\n\r\n      you. He is the most imaginative man in the capital when he has had\r\n\r\n      champagne.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cIvan, you certainly have not had horses served with champagne in pails,\u201d\r\n\r\n       the old boaster, Athanase Georgevitch, protested jealously. He was an\r\n\r\n      advocate, well-known for his table-feats, who claimed the hardest drinking\r\n\r\n      reputation of any man in the capital, and he regretted not to have\r\n\r\n      invented that tale.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cOn my word! And the best brands! I had won four thousand roubles. I left\r\n\r\n      the little fete with fifteen kopecks.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Matrena Petrovna was listening to Ermolai, the faithful country servant\r\n\r\n      who wore always, even here in the city, his habit of fresh nankeen, his\r\n\r\n      black leather belt, his large blue pantaloons and his boots glistening\r\n\r\n      like ice, his country costume in his master\u2019s city home. Madame Matrena\r\n\r\n      rose, after lightly stroking the hair of her step-daughter Natacha, whose\r\n\r\n      eyes followed her to the door, indifferent apparently to the tender\r\n\r\n      manifestations of her father\u2019s orderly, the soldier-poet, Boris Mourazoff,\r\n\r\n      who had written beautiful verses on the death of the Moscow students,\r\n\r\n      after having shot them, in the way of duty, on their barricades.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Ermolai conducted his mistress to the drawing-room and pointed across to a\r\n\r\n      door that he had left open, which led to the sitting-room before Natacha\u2019s\r\n\r\n      chamber.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cHe is there,\u201d said Ermolai in a low voice.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Ermolai need have said nothing, for that matter, since Madame Matrena was\r\n\r\n      aware of a stranger\u2019s presence in the sitting-room by the extraordinary\r\n\r\n      attitude of an individual in a maroon frock-coat bordered with false\r\n\r\n      astrakhan, such as is on the coats of all the Russian police agents and\r\n\r\n      makes the secret agents recognizable at first glance. This policeman was\r\n\r\n      on his knees in the drawing-room watching what passed in the next room\r\n\r\n      through the narrow space of light in the hinge-way of the door. In this\r\n\r\n      manner, or some other, all persons who wished to approach General\r\n\r\n      Trebassof were kept under observation without their knowing it, after\r\n\r\n      having been first searched at the lodge, a measure adopted since the\r\n\r\n      latest attack.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Madame Matrena touched the policeman\u2019s shoulder with that heroic hand\r\n\r\n      which had saved her husband\u2019s life and which still bore traces of the\r\n\r\n      terrible explosion in the last attack, when she had seized the infernal\r\n\r\n      machine intended for the general with her bare hand. The policeman rose\r\n\r\n      and silently left the room, reached the veranda and lounged there on a\r\n\r\n      sofa, pretending to be asleep, but in reality watching the garden paths.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Matrena Petrovna took his place at the hinge-vent. This was her rule; she\r\n\r\n      always took the final glance at everything and everybody. She roved at all\r\n\r\n      hours of the day and night round about the general, like a watch-dog,\r\n\r\n      ready to bite, to throw itself before the danger, to receive the blows, to\r\n\r\n      perish for its master. This had commenced at Moscow after the terrible\r\n\r\n      repression, the massacre of revolutionaries under the walls of Presnia,\r\n\r\n      when the surviving Nihilists left behind them a placard condemning the\r\n\r\n      victorious General Trebassof to death. Matrena Petrovna lived only for the\r\n\r\n      general. She had vowed that she would not survive him. So she had double\r\n\r\n      reason to guard him.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      But she had lost all confidence even within the walls of her own home.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Things had happened even there that defied her caution, her instinct, her\r\n\r\n      love. She had not spoken of these things save to the Chief of Police,\r\n\r\n      Koupriane, who had reported them to the Emperor. And here now was the man\r\n\r\n      whom the Emperor had sent, as the supreme resource, this young stranger\u2014Joseph\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille, reporter.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBut he is a mere boy!\u201d she exclaimed, without at all understanding the\r\n\r\n      matter, this youthful figure, with soft, rounded cheeks, eyes clear and,\r\n\r\n      at first view, extraordinarily naive, the eyes of an infant. True, at the\r\n\r\n      moment Rouletabille\u2019s expression hardly suggested any superhuman\r\n\r\n      profundity of thought, for, left in view of a table, spread with\r\n\r\n      hors-d\u2019oeuvres, the young man appeared solely occupied in digging out with\r\n\r\n      a spoon all the caviare that remained in the jars. Matrena noted the rosy\r\n\r\n      freshness of his cheeks, the absence of down on his lip and not a hint of\r\n\r\n      beard, the thick hair, with the curl over the forehead. Ah, that forehead\u2014the\r\n\r\n      forehead was curious, with great over-hanging cranial lumps which moved\r\n\r\n      above the deep arcade of the eye-sockets while the mouth was busy\u2014well,\r\n\r\n      one would have said that Rouletabille had not eaten for a week. He was\r\n\r\n      demolishing a great slice of Volgan sturgeon, contemplating at the same\r\n\r\n      time with immense interest a salad of creamed cucumbers, when Matrena\r\n\r\n      Petrovna appeared.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      He wished to excuse himself at once and spoke with his mouth full.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI beg your pardon, madame, but the Czar forgot to invite me to\r\n\r\n      breakfast.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Madame Matrena smiled and gave him a hearty handshake as she urged him to\r\n\r\n      be seated.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYou have seen His Majesty?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI come from him, madame. It is to Madame Trebassof that I have the honor\r\n\r\n      of speaking?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYes. And you are Monsieur\u2014?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cJoseph Rouletabille, madame. I do not add, \u2018At your service\u2014because\r\n\r\n      I do not know about that yet. That is what I said just now to His\r\n\r\n      Majesty.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThen?\u201d asked Madame Matrena, rather amused by the tone the conversation\r\n\r\n      had taken and the slightly flurried air of Rouletabille.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWhy, then, I am a reporter, you see. That is what I said at once to my\r\n\r\n      editor in Paris, \u2018I am not going to take part in revolutionary affairs\r\n\r\n      that do not concern my country,\u2019 to which my editor replied, \u2018You do not\r\n\r\n      have to take part. You must go to Russia to make an inquiry into the\r\n\r\n      present status of the different parties. You will commence by interviewing\r\n\r\n      the Emperor.\u2019 I said, \u2018Well, then, here goes,\u2019 and took the train.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAnd you have interviewed the Emperor?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cOh, yes, that has not been difficult. I expected to arrive direct at St.\r\n\r\n      Petersburg, but at Krasnoie-Coelo the train stopped and the grand-marshal\r\n\r\n      of the court came to me and asked me to follow him. It was very\r\n\r\n      flattering. Twenty minutes later I was before His Majesty. He awaited me!\r\n\r\n      I understood at once that this was obviously for something out of the\r\n\r\n      ordinary.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAnd what did he say to you?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cHe is a man of genuine majesty. He reassured me at once when I explained\r\n\r\n      my scruples to him. He said there was no occasion for me to take part in\r\n\r\n      the politics of the matter, but to save his most faithful servant, who was\r\n\r\n      on the point of becoming the victim of the strangest family drama ever\r\n\r\n      conceived.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Madame Matrena, white as a sheet, rose to her feet.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAh,\u201d she said simply.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      But Rouletabille, whom nothing escaped, saw her hand tremble on the back\r\n\r\n      of the chair.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      He went on, not appearing to have noticed her emotion:\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cHis Majesty added these exact words: \u2018It is I who ask it of you; I and\r\n\r\n      Madame Trebassof. Go, monsieur, she awaits you.\u2019\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      He ceased and waited for Madame Trebassof to speak.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      She made up her mind after brief reflection.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cHave you seen Koupriane?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThe Chief of Police? Yes. The grand-marshal accompanied me back to the\r\n\r\n      station at Krasnoie-Coelo, and the Chief of Police accompanied me to St.\r\n\r\n      Petersburg station. One could not have been better received.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMonsieur Rouletabille,\u201d said Matrena, who visibly strove to regain her\r\n\r\n      self-control, \u201cI am not of Koupriane\u2019s opinion and I am not\u201d\u2014here\r\n\r\n      she lowered her trembling voice\u2014\u201cof the opinion His Majesty holds.\r\n\r\n      It is better for me to tell you at once, so that you may not regret\r\n\r\n      intervening in an affair where there are\u2014where there are\u2014risks\u2014terrible\r\n\r\n      risks to run. No, this is not a family drama. The family is small, very\r\n\r\n      small: the general, his daughter Natacha (by his former marriage), and\r\n\r\n      myself. There could not be a family drama among us three. It is simply\r\n\r\n      about my husband, monsieur, who did his duty as a soldier in defending the\r\n\r\n      throne of his sovereign, my husband whom they mean to assassinate! There\r\n\r\n      is nothing else, no other situation, my dear little guest.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      To hide her distress she started to carve a slice of jellied veal and\r\n\r\n      carrot.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYou have not eaten, you are hungry. It is dreadful, my dear young man.\r\n\r\n      See, you must dine with us, and then\u2014you will say adieu. Yes, you\r\n\r\n      will leave me all alone. I will undertake to save him all alone.\r\n\r\n      Certainly, I will undertake it.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      A tear fell on the slice she was cutting. Rouletabille, who felt the brave\r\n\r\n      woman\u2019s emotion affecting him also, braced himself to keep from showing\r\n\r\n      it.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI am able to help you a little all the same,\u201d he said. \u201cMonsieur\r\n\r\n      Koupriane has told me that there is a deep mystery. It is my vocation to\r\n\r\n      get to the bottom of mysteries.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI know what Koupriane thinks,\u201d she said, shaking her head. \u201cBut if I\r\n\r\n      could bring myself to think that for a single day I would rather be dead.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      The good Matrena Petrovna lifted her beautiful eyes to Rouletabille,\r\n\r\n      brimming with the tears she held back.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      She added quickly:\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBut eat now, my dear guest; eat. My dear child, you must forget what\r\n\r\n      Koupriane has said to you, when you are back in France.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI promise you that, madame.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cIt is the Emperor who has caused you this long journey. For me, I did not\r\n\r\n      wish it. Has he, indeed, so much confidence in you?\u201d she asked naively,\r\n\r\n      gazing at him fixedly through her tears.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMadame, I was just about to tell you. I have been active in some\r\n\r\n      important matters that have been reported to him, and then sometimes your\r\n\r\n      Emperor is allowed to see the papers. He has heard talk, too (for\r\n\r\n      everybody talked of them, madame), about the Mystery of the Yellow Room\r\n\r\n      and the Perfume of the Lady in Black.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Here Rouletabille watched Madame Trebassof and was much mortified at the\r\n\r\n      undoubted ignorance that showed in her frank face of either the yellow\r\n\r\n      room or the black perfume.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMy young friend,\u201d said she, in a voice more and more hesitant, \u201cyou must\r\n\r\n      excuse me, but it is a long time since I have had good eyes for reading.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Tears, at last, ran down her cheeks.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille could not restrain himself any further. He saw in one flash\r\n\r\n      all this heroic woman had suffered in her combat day by day with the death\r\n\r\n      which hovered. He took her little fat hands, whose fingers were overloaded\r\n\r\n      with rings, tremulously into his own:\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMadame, do not weep. They wish to kill your husband. Well then, we will\r\n\r\n      be two at least to defend him, I swear to you.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cEven against the Nihilists!\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAye, madame, against all the world. I have eaten all your caviare. I am\r\n\r\n      your guest. I am your friend.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      As he said this he was so excited, so sincere and so droll that Madame\r\n\r\n      Trebassof could not help smiling through her tears. She made him sit down\r\n\r\n      beside her.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThe Chief of Police has talked of you a great deal. He came here abruptly\r\n\r\n      after the last attack and a mysterious happening that I will tell you\r\n\r\n      about. He cried, \u2018Ah, we need Rouletabille to unravel this!\u2019 The next day\r\n\r\n      he came here again. He had gone to the Court. There, everybody, it\r\n\r\n      appears, was talking of you. The Emperor wished to know you. That is why\r\n\r\n      steps were taken through the ambassador at Paris.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYes, yes. And naturally all the world has learned of it. That makes it so\r\n\r\n      lively. The Nihilists warned me immediately that I would not reach Russia\r\n\r\n      alive. That, finally, was what decided me on coming. I am naturally very\r\n\r\n      contrary.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAnd how did you get through the journey?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cNot badly. I discovered at once in the train a young Slav assigned to\r\n\r\n      kill me, and I reached an understanding with him. He was a charming youth,\r\n\r\n      so it was easily arranged.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille was eating away now at strange viands that it would have been\r\n\r\n      difficult for him to name. Matrena Petrovna laid her fat little hand on\r\n\r\n      his arm:\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYou speak seriously?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cVery seriously.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cA small glass of vodka?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cNo alcohol.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Madame Matrena emptied her little glass at a draught.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAnd how did you discover him? How did you know him?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cFirst, he wore glasses. All Nihilists wear glasses when traveling. And\r\n\r\n      then I had a good clew. A minute before the departure from Paris I had a\r\n\r\n      friend go into the corridor of the sleeping-car, a reporter who would do\r\n\r\n      anything I said without even wanting to know why. I said, \u2018You call out\r\n\r\n      suddenly and very loud, \u201cHello, here is Rouletabille.\u201d\u2019 So he called,\r\n\r\n      \u2018Hello, here is Rouletabille,\u2019 and all those who were in the corridor\r\n\r\n      turned and all those who were already in the compartments came out,\r\n\r\n      excepting the man with the glasses. Then I was sure about him.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Madame Trebassof looked at Rouletabille, who turned as red as the comb of a\r\n\r\n      rooster and was rather embarrassed at his fatuity.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThat deserves a rebuff, I know, madame, but from the moment the Emperor\r\n\r\n      of all the Russias had desired to see me I could not admit that any mere\r\n\r\n      man with glasses had not the curiosity to see what I looked like. It was\r\n\r\n      not natural. As soon as the train was off I sat down by this man and told\r\n\r\n      him who I thought he was. I was right. He removed his glasses and, looking\r\n\r\n      me straight in the eyes, said he was glad to have a little talk with me\r\n\r\n      before anything unfortunate happened. A half-hour later the\r\n\r\n      entente-cordiale was signed. I gave him to understand that I was coming\r\n\r\n      here simply on business as a reporter and that there was always time to\r\n\r\n      check me if I should be indiscreet. At the German frontier he left me to\r\n\r\n      go on, and returned tranquilly to his nitro-glycerine.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYou are a marked man also, my poor boy.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cOh, they have not got us yet.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Matrena Petrovna coughed. That us overwhelmed her. With what\r\n\r\n      calmness this boy that she had not known an hour proposed to share the\r\n\r\n      dangers of a situation that excited general pity but from which the\r\n\r\n      bravest kept aloof either from prudence or dismay.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAh, my friend, a little of this fine smoked Hamburg beef?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      But the young man was already pouring out fresh yellow beer.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThere,\u201d said he. \u201cNow, madame, I am listening. Tell me first about the\r\n\r\n      earliest attack.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cNow,\u201d said Matrena, \u201cwe must go to dinner.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille looked at her wide-eyed.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBut, madame, what have I just been doing?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Madame Matrena smiled. All these strangers were alike. Because they had\r\n\r\n      eaten some hors-d\u2019oeuvres, some zakouskis, they imagined their host would\r\n\r\n      be satisfied. They did not know how to eat.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWe will go to the dining-room. The general is expecting you. They are at\r\n\r\n      table.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI understand I am supposed to know him.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYes, you have met in Paris. It is entirely natural that in passing\r\n\r\n      through St. Petersburg you should make him a visit. You know him very well\r\n\r\n      indeed, so well that he opens his home to you. Ah, yes, my step-daughter\r\n\r\n      also\u201d\u2014she flushed a little\u2014\u201cNatacha believes that her father\r\n\r\n      knows you.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      She opened the door of the drawing-room, which they had to cross in order\r\n\r\n      to reach the dining-room.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      From his present position Rouletabille could see all the corners of the\r\n\r\n      drawing-room, the veranda, the garden and the entrance lodge at the gate.\r\n\r\n      In the veranda the man in the maroon frock-coat trimmed with false\r\n\r\n      astrakhan seemed still to be asleep on the sofa; in one of the corners of\r\n\r\n      the drawing-room another individual, silent and motionless as a statue,\r\n\r\n      dressed exactly the same, in a maroon frock-coat with false astrakhan,\r\n\r\n      stood with his hands behind his back seemingly struck with general\r\n\r\n      paralysis at the sight of a flaring sunset which illumined as with a torch\r\n\r\n      the golden spires of Saints Peter and Paul. And in the garden and before\r\n\r\n      the lodge three others dressed in maroon roved like souls in pain over the\r\n\r\n      lawn or back and forth at the entrance. Rouletabille motioned to Madame\r\n\r\n      Matrena, stepped back into the sitting-room and closed the door.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cPolice?\u201d he asked.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Matrena Petrovna nodded her head and put her finger to her mouth in a\r\n\r\n      naive way, as one would caution a child to silence. Rouletabille smiled.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cHow many are there?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cTen, relieved every six hours.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThat makes forty unknown men around your house each day.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cNot unknown,\u201d she replied. \u201cPolice.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYet, in spite of them, you have had the affair of the bouquet in the\r\n\r\n      general\u2019s chamber.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cNo, there were only three then. It is since the affair of the bouquet\r\n\r\n      that there have been ten.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cIt hardly matters. It is since these ten that you have had...\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWhat?\u201d she demanded anxiously.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYou know well\u2014the flooring.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cSh-h-h.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      She glanced at the door, watching the policeman statuesque before the\r\n\r\n      setting sun.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cNo one knows that\u2014not even my husband.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cSo M. Koupriane told me. Then it is you who have arranged for these ten\r\n\r\n      police-agents?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cCertainly.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWell, we will commence now by sending all these police away.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Matrena Petrovna grasped his hand, astounded.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cSurely you don\u2019t think of doing such a thing as that!\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYes. We must know where the blow is coming from. You have four different\r\n\r\n      groups of people around here\u2014the police, the domestics, your\r\n\r\n      friends, your family. Get rid of the police first. They must not be\r\n\r\n      permitted to cross your threshold. They have not been able to protect you.\r\n\r\n      You have nothing to regret. And if, after they are gone, something new\r\n\r\n      turns up, we can leave M. Koupriane to conduct the inquiries without his\r\n\r\n      being preoccupied here at the house.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBut you do not know the admirable police of Koupriane. These brave men\r\n\r\n      have given proof of their devotion.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMadame, if I were face to face with a Nihilist the first thing I would\r\n\r\n      ask myself about him would be, \u2018Is he one of the police?\u2019 The first thing\r\n\r\n      I ask in the presence of an agent of your police is, \u2018Is he not a\r\n\r\n      Nihilist?\u2019\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBut they will not wish to go.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cDo any of them speak French?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYes, their sergeant, who is out there in the salon.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cPray call him.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Madame Trebassof walked into the salon and signaled. The man appeared.\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille handed him a paper, which the other read.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYou will gather your men together and quit the villa,\u201d ordered\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille. \u201cYou will return to the police Headguarters. Say to M.\r\n\r\n      Koupriane that I have commanded this and that I require all police service\r\n\r\n      around the villa to be suspended until further orders.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      The man bowed, appeared not to understand, looked at Madame Trebassof and\r\n\r\n      said to the young man:\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAt your service.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      He went out.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWait here a moment,\u201d urged Madame Trebassof, who did not know how to take\r\n\r\n      this abrupt action and whose anxiety was really painful to see.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      She disappeared after the man of the false astrakhan. A few moments\r\n\r\n      afterwards she returned. She appeared even more agitated.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI beg your pardon,\u201d she murmured, \u201cbut I cannot let them go like this.\r\n\r\n      They are much chagrined. They have insisted on knowing where they have\r\n\r\n      failed in their service. I have appeased them with money.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYes, and tell me the whole truth, madame. You have directed them not to\r\n\r\n      go far away, but to remain near the villa so as to watch it as closely as\r\n\r\n      possible.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      She reddened.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cIt is true. But they have gone, nevertheless. They had to obey you. What\r\n\r\n      can that paper be you have shown them?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille drew out again the billet covered with seals and signs and\r\n\r\n      cabalistics that he did not understand. Madame Trebassof translated it\r\n\r\n      aloud: \u201cOrder to all officials in surveillance of the Villa Trebassof to\r\n\r\n      obey the bearer absolutely. Signed: Koupriane.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cIs it possible!\u201d murmured Matrena Petrovna. \u201cBut Koupriane would never\r\n\r\n      have given you this paper if he had imagined that you would use it to\r\n\r\n      dismiss his agents.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cEvidently. I have not asked him his advice, madame, you may be sure. But\r\n\r\n      I will see him to-morrow and he will understand.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMeanwhile, who is going to watch over him?\u201d cried she.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille took her hands again. He saw her suffering, a prey to anguish\r\n\r\n      almost prostrating. He pitied her. He wished to give her immediate\r\n\r\n      confidence.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWe will,\u201d he said.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      She saw his young, clear eyes, so deep, so intelligent, the well-formed\r\n\r\n      young head, the willing face, all his young ardency for her, and it\r\n\r\n      reassured her. Rouletabille waited for what she might say. She said\r\n\r\n      nothing. She took him in her arms and embraced him.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n \r\n\r\n\r\n      II. NATACHA\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      In the dining-room it was Thaddeus Tchnichnikoff\u2019s turn to tell hunting\r\n\r\n      stories. He was the greatest timber-merchant in Lithuania. He owned\r\n\r\n      immense forests and he loved Feodor Feodorovitch* as a brother, for they\r\n\r\n      had played together all through their childhood, and once he had saved him\r\n\r\n      from a bear that was just about to crush his skull as one might knock off\r\n\r\n      a hat. General Trebassof\u2019s father was governor of Courlande at that time,\r\n\r\n      by the grace of God and the Little Father. Thaddeus, who was just thirteen\r\n\r\n      years old, killed the bear with a single stroke of his boar-spear, and\r\n\r\n      just in time. Close ties were knit between the two families by this\r\n\r\n      occurrence, and though Thaddeus was neither noble-born nor a soldier,\r\n\r\n      Feodor considered him his brother and felt toward him as such. Now\r\n\r\n      Thaddeus had become the greatest timber-merchant of the western provinces,\r\n\r\n      with his own forests and also with his massive body, his fat, oily face,\r\n\r\n      his bull-neck and his ample paunch. He quitted everything at once\u2014all\r\n\r\n      his affairs, his family\u2014as soon as he learned of the first attack,\r\n\r\n      to come and remain by the side of his dear comrade Feodor. He had done\r\n\r\n      this after each attack, without forgetting one. He was a faithful friend.\r\n\r\n      But he fretted because they might not go bear-hunting as in their youth.\r\n\r\n      \u2018Where, he would ask, are there any bears remaining in Courlande, or trees\r\n\r\n      for that matter, what you could call trees, growing since the days of the\r\n\r\n      grand-dukes of Lithuania, giant trees that threw their shade right up to\r\n\r\n      the very edge of the towns? Where were such things nowadays? Thaddeus was\r\n\r\n      very amusing, for it was he, certainly, who had cut them away tranquilly\r\n\r\n      enough and watched them vanish in locomotive smoke. It was what was called\r\n\r\n      Progress. Ah, hunting lost its national character assuredly with tiny\r\n\r\n      new-growth trees which had not had time to grow. And, besides, one\r\n\r\n      nowadays had not time for hunting. All the big game was so far away. Lucky\r\n\r\n      enough if one seized the time to bring down a brace of woodcock early in\r\n\r\n      the morning. At this point in Thaddeus\u2019s conversation there was a babble\r\n\r\n      of talk among the convivial gentlemen, for they had all the time in the\r\n\r\n      world at their disposal and could not see why he should be so concerned\r\n\r\n      about snatching a little while at morning or evening, or at midday for\r\n\r\n      that matter. Champagne was flowing like a river when Rouletabille was\r\n\r\n      brought in by Matrena Petrovna. The general, whose eyes had been on the\r\n\r\n      door for some time, cried at once, as though responding to a cue:\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAh, my dear Rouletabille! I have been looking for you. Our friends wrote\r\n\r\n      me you were coming to St. Petersburg.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille hurried over to him and they shook hands like friends who\r\n\r\n      meet after a long separation. The reporter was presented to the company as\r\n\r\n      a close young friend from Paris whom they had enjoyed so much during their\r\n\r\n      latest visit to the City of Light. Everybody inquired for the latest word\r\n\r\n      of Paris as of a dear acquaintance.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cHow is everybody at Maxim\u2019s?\u201d urged the excellent Athanase Georgevitch.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Thaddeus, too, had been once in Paris and he returned with an enthusiastic\r\n\r\n      liking for the French demoiselles.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cVos gogottes, monsieur,\u201d he said, appearing very amiable and leaning on\r\n\r\n      each word, with a guttural emphasis such as is common in the western\r\n\r\n      provinces, \u201cah, vos gogottes!\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Matrena Perovna tried to silence him, but Thaddeus insisted on his right\r\n\r\n      to appreciate the fair sex away from home. He had a turgid, sentimental\r\n\r\n      wife, always weeping and cramming her religious notions down his throat.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Of course someone asked Rouletabille what he thought of Russia, but he had\r\n\r\n      no more than opened his mouth to reply than Athanase Georgevitch closed it\r\n\r\n      by interrupting:\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cPermettez! Permettez! You others, of the young generation, what do you\r\n\r\n      know of it? You need to have lived a long time and in all its districts to\r\n\r\n      appreciate Russia at its true value. Russia, my young sir, is as yet a\r\n\r\n      closed book to you.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cNaturally,\u201d Rouletabille answered, smiling.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWell, well, here\u2019s your health! What I would point out to you first of\r\n\r\n      all is that it is a good buyer of champagne, eh?\u201d\u2014and he gave a huge\r\n\r\n      grin. \u201cBut the hardest drinker I ever knew was born on the banks of the\r\n\r\n      Seine. Did you know him, Feodor Feodorovitch? Poor Charles Dufour, who\r\n\r\n      died two years ago at fete of the officers of the Guard. He wagered at the\r\n\r\n      end of the banquet that he could drink a glassful of champagne to the\r\n\r\n      health of each man there. There were sixty when you came to count them. He\r\n\r\n      commenced the round of the table and the affair went splendidly up to the\r\n\r\n      fifty-eighth man. But at the fifty-ninth\u2014think of the misfortune!\u2014the\r\n\r\n      champagne ran out! That poor, that charming, that excellent Charles took\r\n\r\n      up a glass of vin dore which was in the glass of this fifty-ninth, wished\r\n\r\n      him long life, drained the glass at one draught, had just time to murmur,\r\n\r\n      \u2018Tokay, 1807,\u2019 and fell back dead! Ah, he knew the brands, my word! and he\r\n\r\n      proved it to his last breath! Peace to his ashes! They asked what he died\r\n\r\n      of. I knew he died because of the inappropriate blend of flavors. There\r\n\r\n      should be discipline in all things and not promiscuous mixing. One more\r\n\r\n      glass of champagne and he would have been drinking with us this evening.\r\n\r\n      Your health, Matrena Petrovna. Champagne, Feodor Feodorovitch! Vive la\r\n\r\n      France, monsieur! Natacha, my child, you must sing something. Boris will\r\n\r\n      accompany you on the guzla. Your father will enjoy it.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      All eyes turned toward Natacha as she rose.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille was struck by her serene beauty. That was the first\r\n\r\n      enthralling impression, an impression so strong it astonished him, the\r\n\r\n      perfect serenity, the supreme calm, the tranquil harmony of her noble\r\n\r\n      features. Natacha was twenty. Heavy brown hair circled about er forehead\r\n\r\n      and was looped about her ears, which were half-concealed. Her profile was\r\n\r\n      clear-cut; her mouth was strong and revealed between red, firm lips the\r\n\r\n      even pearliness of her teeth. She was of medium height.
