If you were one of my subjects I would have already started you on\r\n\r\n      the road to the Ural Mountains.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI remove myself farther, Sire.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMonsieur, I pray you not to interrupt me and not to speak unless I ask\r\n\r\n      you a question.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cOh, pardon, Sire, pardon.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI am not duped by the pretext you have offered Monsieur le Grand-Marechal\r\n\r\n      in order to penetrate here.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cIt is not a pretext, Sire.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAgain!\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cOh, pardon, Sire, pardon.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI say to you that, called here to aid me against my enemies, they\r\n\r\n      themselves have not found a stronger or more criminal support than in\r\n\r\n      you.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cOf what am I accused, Sire?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cKoupriane\u2014\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAh! Ah! ... Pardon!\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMy Chief of Police justly complains that you have traversed all his\r\n\r\n      designs and that you have taken it upon yourself to ruin them. First, you\r\n\r\n      removed his agents, who inconvenienced you, it seems; then, the moment\r\n\r\n      that he had the proof in hand of the abominable alliance of Natacha\r\n\r\n      Feodorovna with the Nihilists who attempt the assassination of her father\r\n\r\n      your intervention has permitted that proof to escape him. And you have\r\n\r\n      boasted of the feat, monsieur, so that we can only consider you\r\n\r\n      responsible for the attempts that followed.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWithout you, Natacha would not have attempted to poison her father.\r\n\r\n      Without you, they would not have sent to find physicians who could blow up\r\n\r\n      the datcha des Iles. Finally, no later than yesterday, when this faithful\r\n\r\n      servant of mine had set a trap they could not have escaped from, you have\r\n\r\n      had the audacity, you, to warn them of it. They owe their escape to you.\r\n\r\n      Monsieur, those are attempts against the security of the State which\r\n\r\n      deserves the heaviest punishment. Why, you went out one day from here\r\n\r\n      promising me to save General Trebassof from all the plotting assassins who\r\n\r\n      lurked about him. And then you play the game of the assassins! Your\r\n\r\n      conduct is as miserable as that of Natacha Feodorovna is monstrous!\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      The Emperor ceased, and looked at Rouletabille, who had not lowered his\r\n\r\n      eyes.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWhat can you say for yourself? Speak\u2014now.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI can only say to Your Majesty that I come to take leave of you because\r\n\r\n      my task here is finished. I have promised you the life of General\r\n\r\n      Trebassof, and I bring it to you. He runs no danger any more! I say\r\n\r\n      further to Your Majesty that there exists nowhere in the world a daughter\r\n\r\n      more devoted to her father, even to the death, a daughter more sublime\r\n\r\n      than Natacha Feodorovna, nor more innocent.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBe careful, monsieur. I inform you that I have studied this affair\r\n\r\n      personally and very closely. You have the proofs of these statements you\r\n\r\n      advance?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYes, Sire.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAnd I, I have the proofs that Natacha Feodorovna is a renegade.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      At this contradiction, uttered in a firm voice, the Emperor stirred, a\r\n\r\n      flush of anger and of outraged majesty in his face. But, after this first\r\n\r\n      movement, he succeeded in controlling himself, opened a drawer brusquely,\r\n\r\n      took out some papers and threw them on the table.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cHere they are.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille reached for the papers.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYou do not read Russian, monsieur. I will translate their purport for\r\n\r\n      you. Know, then, that there has been a mysterious exchange of letters\r\n\r\n      between Natacha Feodorovna and the Central Revolutionary Committee, and\r\n\r\n      that these letters show the daughter of General Trebassof to be in perfect\r\n\r\n      accord with the assassins of her father for the execution of their\r\n\r\n      abominable project.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThe death of the general?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cExactly.\u201d\r\n\r\n\t \t \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI declare to Your Majesty that that is not possible.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cObstinate man! I will read\u2014\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cUseless, Sire. It is impossible. There may be in them the question of a\r\n\r\n      project, but I am greatly surprised if these conspirators have been\r\n\r\n      sufficiently imprudent to write in those letters that they count on\r\n\r\n      Natacha to poison her father.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThat, as a matter of fact, is not written, and you yourself are\r\n\r\n      responsible for it not being there. It does not follow any the less that\r\n\r\n      Natacha Feodorovna had an understanding with the Nihilists.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThat is correct, Sire.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAh, you confess that?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI do not confess; I simply affirm that Natacha had an understanding with\r\n\r\n      the Nihilists.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWho plotted their abominable attacks against the ex-Governor of Moscow.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cSire, since Natacha had an understanding with the Nihilists, it was not\r\n\r\n      to kill her father, but to save him. And the project of which you hold\r\n\r\n      here the proofs, but of whose character you are unaware, is to end the\r\n\r\n      attacks of which you speak, instantly.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYou say that.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI speak the truth, Sire.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWhere are the proofs? Show me your papers.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI have none. I have only my word.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThat is not sufficient.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cIt will be sufficient, once you have heard me.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI listen.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cSire, before revealing to you a secret on which depends the life of\r\n\r\n      General Trebassof, you must permit me some questions. Your Majesty holds\r\n\r\n      the life of the general very dear?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWhat has that to do with it?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cPardon. I desire that Your Majesty assure me on that point.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThe general has protected my throne. He has saved the Empire from one of\r\n\r\n      the greatest dangers that it has ever run. If the servant who has done\r\n\r\n      such a service should be rewarded by death, by the punishment that the\r\n\r\n      enemies of my people prepare for him in the darkness, I should never\r\n\r\n      forgive myself. There have been too many martyrs already!\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYou have replied to me, Sire, in such a way that you make me understand\r\n\r\n      there is no sacrifice\u2014even to the sacrifice of your amour-propre the\r\n\r\n      greatest a ruler can suffer\u2014no sacrifice too dear to ransom from\r\n\r\n      death one of these martyrs.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAh, ah! These gentlemen lay down conditions to me! Money. Money. They\r\n\r\n      need money. And at how much do they rate the head of the general?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cSire, that does not touch Your Majesty, and I never will come to offer\r\n\r\n      you such a bargain. That matter concerns only Natacha Feodorovna, who has\r\n\r\n      offered her fortune!\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cHer fortune! But she has nothing.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cShe will have one at the death of the general. Now she engages to give it\r\n\r\n      all to the Revolutionary Committee the day the general dies\u2014if he\r\n\r\n      dies a natural death!\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      The Emperor rose, greatly agitated.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cTo the Revolutionary Party! What do you tell me! The fortune of the\r\n\r\n      general! Eh, but these are great riches.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cSire, I have told you the secret. You alone should know it and guard it\r\n\r\n      forever, and I have your sacred word that, when the hour comes, you will\r\n\r\n      let the prize go where it is promised. If the general ever learns of such\r\n\r\n      a thing, such a treaty, he would easily arrange that nothing should\r\n\r\n      remain, and he would denounce his daughter who has saved him, and then he\r\n\r\n      would promptly be the prey of his enemies and yours, from whom you wish to\r\n\r\n      save him. I have told the secret not to the Emperor, but to the\r\n\r\n      representative of God on the Russian earth. I have confessed it to the\r\n\r\n      priest, who is bound to forget the words uttered only before God. Allow\r\n\r\n      Natacha Feodorovna her own way, Sire! And her father, your servant, whose\r\n\r\n      life is so dear to you, is saved. At the natural death of the general his\r\n\r\n      fortune will go to his daughter, who has disposed of it.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille stopped a moment to judge of the effect produced. It was not\r\n\r\n      good. The face of his august listener was more and more in a frown.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      The silence continued, and now the reporter did not dare to break it. He\r\n\r\n      waited.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Finally, the Emperor rose and walked forward and backward across the room,\r\n\r\n      deep in thought. For a moment he stopped at the window and waved\r\n\r\n      paternally to the little Tsarevitch, who played in the park with the\r\n\r\n      grand-duchesses.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Then he returned to Rouletabille and pinched his ear.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBut, tell me, how have you learned all this? And who then has poisoned\r\n\r\n      the general and his wife, in the kiosk, if not Natacha?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cNatacha is a saint. It is nothing, Sire, that she has been raised in\r\n\r\n      luxury, and vows herself to misery; but it is sublime that she guards in\r\n\r\n      her heart the secret of her sacrifice from everyone, and, in spite of all,\r\n\r\n      because secrecy is necessary and has been required of her. See her\r\n\r\n      guarding it before her father, who has been brought to believe in the\r\n\r\n      dishonor of his daughter, and still to be silent when a word would have\r\n\r\n      proved her innocent; guarding it face to face with her fiance, whom she\r\n\r\n      loves, and repulses because marriage is forbidden to the girl who is\r\n\r\n      supposed to be rich and who will be poor; guarding it, above all\u2014and\r\n\r\n      guarding it still\u2014in the depths of the dungeon, and ready to take\r\n\r\n      the road to Siberia under the accusation of assassination, because that\r\n\r\n      ignominy is necessary for the safety of her father. That, Sire\u2014oh,\r\n\r\n      Sire, do you see!\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBut you, how have you been able to penetrate into this guarded secret?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBy watching her eyes. By observing, when she believed herself alone, the\r\n\r\n      look of terror and the gleams of love. And, beyond all, by looking at her\r\n\r\n      when she was looking at her father. Ah, Sire, there were moments when on\r\n\r\n      her mystic face one could read the wild joy and devotion of the martyr.\r\n\r\n      Then, by listening and by piecing together scraps of phrases inconsistent\r\n\r\n      with the idea of treachery, but which immediately acquired meaning if one\r\n\r\n      thought of the opposite, of sacrifice. Ah, that is it, Sire! Consider\r\n\r\n      always the alternative motive. What I finally could see myself, the\r\n\r\n      others, who had a fixed opinion about Natacha, could not see. And why had\r\n\r\n      they their fixed opinion? Simply because the idea of compromise with the\r\n\r\n      Nihilists aroused at once the idea of complicity! For such people it is\r\n\r\n      always the same thing\u2014they never can see but the one side of the\r\n\r\n      situation. But, nevertheless, the situation had two sides, as all\r\n\r\n      situations have. The question was simple. The compromise was certain. But\r\n\r\n      why had Natacha compromised herself with the Nihilists? Was it necessarily\r\n\r\n      in order to lose her father? Might it not be, on the contrary, in order to\r\n\r\n      save him? When one has rendezvous with an enemy it is not necessarily to\r\n\r\n      enter into his game, sometimes it is to disarm him with an offer. Between\r\n\r\n      these two hypotheses, which I alone took the trouble to examine, I did not\r\n\r\n      hesitate long, because Natacha\u2019s every attitude proclaimed her innocence:\r\n\r\n      and her eyes, Sire, in which one read purity and love, prevailed always\r\n\r\n      with me against all the passing appearances of disgrace and crime.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI saw that Natacha negotiated with them. But what had she to place in the\r\n\r\n      scales against the life of her father? Nothing\u2014except the fortune\r\n\r\n      that she would have one day.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cSome words she spoke about the impossibility of immediate marriage, about\r\n\r\n      poverty which could always knock at the door of any mansion, remarks that\r\n\r\n      I was able to overhear between Natacha and Boris Mourazoff, which to him\r\n\r\n      meant nothing, put me definitely on the right road. And I was not long in\r\n\r\n      ascertaining that the negotiations in this formidable affair were taking\r\n\r\n      place in the very house of Trebassof! Pursued without by the incessant\r\n\r\n      spying of Koupriane, who sought to surprise her in company with the\r\n\r\n      Nihilists, watched closely, too, by the jealous supervision of Boris, who\r\n\r\n      was jealous of Michael Nikolaievitch, she had to seize the only\r\n\r\n      opportunities possible for such negotiations, at night, in her own home,\r\n\r\n      the sole place where, by the very audacity of it, she was able to play her\r\n\r\n      part in any security.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMichael Nikolaievitch knew Annouchka. There was certainly the point of\r\n\r\n      departure for the negotiations which that felon-officer, traitor to all\r\n\r\n      sides, worked at will toward the realization of his own infamous project.\r\n\r\n      I do not think that Michael ever confided to Natacha that he was, from the\r\n\r\n      very first, the instrument of the revolutionaries. Natacha, who sought to\r\n\r\n      get in touch with the revolutionary party, had to entrust him with a\r\n\r\n      correspondence for Annouchka, following which he assumed direction of the\r\n\r\n      affair, deceiving the Nihilists, who, in their absolute penury, following\r\n\r\n      the revolt, had been seduced by the proposition of General Trebassof\u2019s\r\n\r\n      daughter, and deceiving Natacha, whom he pretended to love and by whom he\r\n\r\n      believed himself loved. At this point in the affair Natacha came to\r\n\r\n      understand that it was necessary to propitiate Michael Nikolaievitch, her\r\n\r\n      indispensable intermediary, and she managed to do it so well that Boris\r\n\r\n      Mourazoff felt the blackest jealousy. On his side, Michael came to believe\r\n\r\n      that Natacha would have no other husband than himself, but he did not\r\n\r\n      propose to marry a penniless girl! And, fatally, it followed that Natacha,\r\n\r\n      in that infernal intrigue, negotiated for the life of her father through\r\n\r\n      the agency of a man who, underhandedly, sought to strike at the general\r\n\r\n      himself, because the immediate death of her father before the negotiation\r\n\r\n      was completed would enrich Natacha, who had given Michael so much to hope.\r\n\r\n      That frightful tragedy, Sire, in which we have lived our most painful\r\n\r\n      hours, appeared to me, confident of Natacha\u2019s innocence, as absolutely\r\n\r\n      simple as for the others it seemed complicated. Natacha believed she had\r\n\r\n      in Michael Nikolaievitch a man who worked for her, but he worked only for\r\n\r\n      himself. The day that I was convinced of it, Sire, by my examination of\r\n\r\n      the approach to the balcony, I had a mind to warn Natacha, to go to her\r\n\r\n      and say, \u2018Get rid of that man. He will betray you. If you need an agent, I\r\n\r\n      am at your service.\u2019 But that day, at Krestowsky, destiny prevented my\r\n\r\n      rejoining Natacha; and I must attribute it to destiny, which would not\r\n\r\n      permit the loss of that man. Michael Nikolaievitch, who was a traitor, was\r\n\r\n      too much in the \u2018combination,\u2019 and if he had been rejected he would have\r\n\r\n      ruined everything. I caused him to disappear! The great misfortune then\r\n\r\n      was that Natacha, holding me responsible for the death of a man she\r\n\r\n      believed innocent, never wished to see me again, and, when she did see me,\r\n\r\n      refused to have any conversation with me because I proposed that I take\r\n\r\n      Michael\u2019s place for her with the revolutionaries. She would have nothing\r\n\r\n      to do with me in order to protect her secret. Meantime, the Nihilists\r\n\r\n      believed they were betrayed by Natacha when they learned of the death of\r\n\r\n      Michael, and they undertook to avenge him. They seized Natacha, and bore\r\n\r\n      her off by force. The unhappy girl learned then, that same evening, of the\r\n\r\n      attack which destroyed the datcha and, happily, still spared her father.\r\n\r\n      This time she reached a definite understanding with the revolutionary\r\n\r\n      party. Her bargain was made. I offer you for proof of it only her attitude\r\n\r\n      when she was arrested, and, even in that moment, her sublime silence.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      While Rouletabille urged his view, the Emperor let him talk on and on, and\r\n\r\n      now his eyes were dim.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cIs it possible that Natacha has not been the accomplice, in all, of\r\n\r\n      Michael Nikolaievitch?\u201d he demanded. \u201cIt was she who opened her father\u2019s\r\n\r\n      house to him that night. If she was not his accomplice she would have\r\n\r\n      mistrusted him, she would have watched him.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cSire, Michael Nikolaievitch was a very clever man. He knew so well how to\r\n\r\n      play upon Natacha, and Annouchka, in whom she placed all her hope. It was\r\n\r\n      from Annouchka that she wished to hold the life of her father. It was the\r\n\r\n      word, the signature of Annouchka that she demanded before giving her own.\r\n\r\n      The evening Michael Nikolaievitch died, he was charged to bring her that\r\n\r\n      signature. I know it, myself, because, pretending drunkenness, I was able\r\n\r\n      to overhear enough of a conversation between Annouchka and a man whose\r\n\r\n      name I must conceal. Yes, that last evening, Michael Nikolaievitch, when\r\n\r\n      he entered the datcha, had the signature in his pocket, but also he\r\n\r\n      carried the weapon or the poison with which he already had attempted and\r\n\r\n      was resolved to reach the father of her whom he believed was assuredly to\r\n\r\n      be his wife.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYou speak now of a paper, very precious, that I regret not to possess,\r\n\r\n      monsieur,\u201d said the Tsar coldly, \u201cbecause that paper alone would have\r\n\r\n      proved to me the innocence of your protegee.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cIf you have not it, Sire, you know well that it is because I have wished\r\n\r\n      you to have it. The corpse had been searched by Katharina, the little\r\n\r\n      Bohemian, and I, Sire, prevented Koupriane from finding that signature in\r\n\r\n      Katharina\u2019s possession. In saving the secret I have saved General\r\n\r\n      Trebassof\u2019s life, who would have preferred to die rather than accept such\r\n\r\n      an arrangement.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      The Tsar stopped Rouletabille in his enthusiastic outburst.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAll that would be very beautiful and perhaps admirable,\u201d said he, more\r\n\r\n      and more coldly, because he had entirely recovered himself, \u201cif Natacha\r\n\r\n      had not, herself, with her own hand, poisoned her father and her\r\n\r\n      step-mother!\u2014always with arsenate of soda.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cOh, some of that had been left in the house,\u201d replied Rouletabille. \u201cThey\r\n\r\n      had not given me all of it for the analysis after the first attempt. But\r\n\r\n      Natacha is innocent of that, Sire. I swear it to you. As true as that I\r\n\r\n      have certainly escaped being hanged.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cHow, hanged?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cOh, it has not amounted to much now, Your Majesty.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      And Rouletabille recounted his sinister adventure, up to the moment of his\r\n\r\n      death, or, rather, up to the moment when he had believed he was going to\r\n\r\n      die.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      The Emperor listened to the young reporter with complete stupefaction. He\r\n\r\n      murmured, \u201cPoor lad!\u201d then, suddenly:\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBut how have you managed to escape them?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cSire they have given me twenty-four hours for you to set Natacha at\r\n\r\n      liberty, that is to say, that you restore her to her rights, all her\r\n\r\n      rights, and she be always the recognized heiress of Trebassof. Do you\r\n\r\n      understand me, Sire?\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI will understand you, perhaps, when you have explained to me how Natacha\r\n\r\n      has not poisoned her father and step-mother.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThere are some things so simple, Sire, that one is able to think of them\r\n\r\n      only with a rope around one\u2019s neck. But let us reason it out. We have here\r\n\r\n      four persons, two of whom have been poisoned and the other two with them\r\n\r\n      have not been. Now, it is certain that, of the four persons, the general\r\n\r\n      has not wished to poison himself, that his wife has not wished to poison\r\n\r\n      the general, and that, as for me, I have not wished to poison anybody.\r\n\r\n      That, if we are absolutely sure of it, leaves as the poisoner only\r\n\r\n      Natacha. That is so certain, so inevitable, that there is only one case,\r\n\r\n      one alone, where, in such conditions, Natacha would not be regarded as the\r\n\r\n      poisoner.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI confess that, logically, I do not see,\u201d said the Tsar, \u201canything beyond\r\n\r\n      that but more and more of a tangle. What is it?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cLogically, the only case would be that where no one had been poisoned,\r\n\r\n      that is to say, where no one had taken any poison.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBut the presence of the poison has been established!\u201d cried the Emperor.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cStill, the presence of the poison proves only its presence, not the\r\n\r\n      crime. Both poison and ipecac were found in the stomach expulsions. From\r\n\r\n      which a crime has been concluded. What state of affairs was necessary for\r\n\r\n      there to have been no crime? Simply that the poison should have appeared\r\n\r\n      in the expulsions after the ipecac. Then there would have been no\r\n\r\n      poisoning, but everyone would believe there had been. And, for that,\r\n\r\n      someone would have poured the poison into the expulsions.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      The Tsar never quitted Rouletabille\u2019s eyes.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThat is extraordinary,\u201d said he. \u201cBut of course it is possible. In any\r\n\r\n      case, it is still only an hypothesis.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAnd so long as it could be an hypothesis that no one thought of, it could\r\n\r\n      be just that, Sire. But if I am here, it is because I have the proof that\r\n\r\n      that hypothesis corresponds to the reality. That necessary proof of\r\n\r\n      Natacha\u2019s innocence, Your Majesty, I have found with the rope around my\r\n\r\n      neck. Ah, I tell you it was time! What has hindered us hitherto, I do not\r\n\r\n      say to realize, but even to think, of that hypothesis? Simply that we\r\n\r\n      thought the illness of the general had commenced before the absorption of\r\n\r\n      the ipecac, since Matrena Petrovna had been obliged to go for it to her\r\n\r\n      medicine-closet after his illness commenced, in order to counteract the\r\n\r\n      poison of which she also appeared to be the victim.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBut, if I acquire proof that Matrena Petrovna had the ipecac at hand\r\n\r\n      before the sickness, my hypothesis of pretense at poisoning has\r\n\r\n      irresistible force. Because, if it was not to use it before, why did she\r\n\r\n      have it with her before? And if it was not that she wished to hide the\r\n\r\n      fact that she had used it before, why did she wish to make believe that\r\n\r\n      she went to find it afterwards?\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThen, in order to show Natacha\u2019s innocence, here is what must be proved:\r\n\r\n      that Matrena Petrovna had the ipecac on her, even when she went to look\r\n\r\n      for it.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYoung Rouletabille, I hardly breathe,\u201d said the Tsar.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBreathe, Sire. The proof is here. Matrena Petrovna necessarily had the\r\n\r\n      ipecac on her, because after the sickness she had not the time for going\r\n\r\n      to find it. Do you understand, Sire? Between the moment when she fled from\r\n\r\n      the kiosk and when she returned there, she had not the actual time to go\r\n\r\n      to her medicine-closet to find the ipecac.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cHow have you been able to compute the time?\u201d asked the Emperor.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cSire, the Lord God directed, Who made me admire Feodor Feodorovitch\u2019s\r\n\r\n      watch just when we went to read, and to read on the dial of that watch two\r\n\r\n      minutes to the hour, and the Lord God directed yet, Who, after the scene\r\n\r\n      of the poison, at the time Matrena returned carrying the ipecac publicly,\r\n\r\n      made the hour strike from that watch in the general\u2019s pocket.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cTwo minutes. It was impossible for Matrena to have covered that distance\r\n\r\n      in two minutes. She could only have entered the deserted datcha and left\r\n\r\n      it again instantly. She had not taken the trouble to mount to the floor\r\n\r\n      above, where, she told us and repeated when she returned, the ipecac was\r\n\r\n      in the medicine-closet. She lied! And if she lied, all is explained.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cIt was the striking of a watch, Sire, with a striking apparatus and a\r\n\r\n      sound like the general\u2019s, there in the quarters of the revolutionaries,\r\n\r\n      that roused my memory and indicated to me in a second this argument of the\r\n\r\n      time.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI got down from my gallows-scaffold, Your Majesty, to experiment on that\r\n\r\n      time-limit. Oh, nothing and nobody could have prevented my making that\r\n\r\n      experiment before I died, to prove to myself that Rouletabille had all\r\n\r\n      along been right. I had studied the grounds around the datcha enough to be\r\n\r\n      perfectly exact about the distances. I found in the court where I was to\r\n\r\n      be hanged the same number of steps that there were from the kiosk to the\r\n\r\n      steps of the veranda, and, as the staircase of the revolutionaries had\r\n\r\n      fewer steps, I lengthened my journey a few steps by walking around a\r\n\r\n      chair. Finally, I attended to the opening and closing of the doors that\r\n\r\n      Matrena would have had to do. I had looked at a watch when I started. When\r\n\r\n      I returned, Sire, and looked at the watch again, I had taken three minutes\r\n\r\n      to cover the distance\u2014and it is not for me to boast, but I am a\r\n\r\n      little livelier than the excellent Matrena.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMatrena had lied. Matrena had simulated the poisoning of the general.\r\n\r\n      Matrena had coolly poured ipecac in the general\u2019s glass while we were\r\n\r\n      illustrating with matches a curious-enough theory of the nature of the\r\n\r\n      constitution of the empire.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cBut this is abominable!\u201d cried the Emperor, this time definitely\r\n\r\n      convinced by the intricate argument of Rouletabille. \u201cAnd what end could\r\n\r\n      this imitation serve?\u2019\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThe end of preventing the real crime! The end that she believed herself\r\n\r\n      to have attained, Sire, to have Natacha removed forever\u2014Natacha whom\r\n\r\n      she believed capable of any crime.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cOh, it is monstrous! Feodor Feodorovitch has often told me that Matrena\r\n\r\n      loved Natacha sincerely.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cShe loved her sincerely up to the day that she believed her guilty.\r\n\r\n      Matrena Petrovna was sure of Natacha\u2019s complicity in Michael\r\n\r\n      Nikolaievitch\u2019s attempt to poison the general. I shared her stupor, her\r\n\r\n      despair, when Feodor Feodorovitch took his daughter in his arms after that\r\n\r\n      tragic night, and embraced her. He seemed to absolve her. It was then that\r\n\r\n      Matrena resolved within herself to save the general in spite of himself,\r\n\r\n      but I remain persuaded that, if she had dared such a plan against Natacha,\r\n\r\n      it would only be because of what she believed definite proof of her\r\n\r\n      step-daughter\u2019s infamy. These papers, Sire, that you have shown me, and\r\n\r\n      which show, if nothing more, an understanding between Natacha and the\r\n\r\n      revolutionaries, could only have been in the possession of Michael or of\r\n\r\n      Natacha. Nothing was found in Michael\u2019s quarters. Tell me, then, that\r\n\r\n      Matrena found them in Natacha\u2019s apartment. Then, she did not hesitate!\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cIf one outlined her crime to her, do you believe she would confess it?\u201d\r\n\r\n      asked the Emperor.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI am so sure of it that I have had her brought here. By now Koupriane\r\n\r\n      should be here at the chateau, with Matrena Petrovna.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYou think of everything, monsieur.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      The Tsar moved to ring a bell. Rouletabille raised his hand.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cNot yet, Sire. I ask that you permit me not to be present at the\r\n\r\n      confusion of that brave, heroic, good woman who has loved me much. But\r\n\r\n      before I go, Sire\u2014do you promise me?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      The Emperor believed he had not heard correctly or did not grasp the\r\n\r\n      meaning. He repeated what Rouletabille had said. The young reporter\r\n\r\n      repeated it once more:\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cDo you promise? No, Sire, I am not mad. I dare to ask you that. I have\r\n\r\n      confided my honor to Your Majesty. I have told you Natacha\u2019s secret. Well,\r\n\r\n      now, before Matrena\u2019s confession, I dare to ask you: Promise me to forget\r\n\r\n      that secret. It will not suffice merely to give Natacha back again to her\r\n\r\n      father. It is necessary to leave her course open to her\u2014if you\r\n\r\n      really wish to save General Trebassof. What do you decide, Sire?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cIt is the first time anyone has questioned me, monsieur.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAh, well, it will be the last. But I humbly beg Your Majesty to reply.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThat would be many millions given to the Revolution.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cOh, Sire, they are not given yet. The general is sixty-five, but he has\r\n\r\n      many years ahead of him, if you wish it. By the time he dies\u2014a\r\n\r\n      natural death, if you wish it\u2014your enemies will have disarmed.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMy enemies!\u201d murmured the Tsar in a low voice. \u201cNo, no; my enemies never\r\n\r\n      will disarm. Who, then, will be able to disarm them?\u201d added he,\r\n\r\n      melancholily, shaking his head.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cProgress, Sire! If you wish it.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      The Tsar turned red and looked at the audacious young man, who met the\r\n\r\n      gaze of His Majesty frankly.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cIt is kind of you to say that, my young friend. But you speak as a\r\n\r\n      child.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAs a child of France to the Father of the Russian people.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      It was said in a voice so solemn and, at the same time, so naively\r\n\r\n      touching, that the Tsar started. He gazed again for some time in silence\r\n\r\n      at this boy who, this time, turned away his brimming eyes.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cProgress and pity, Sire.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWell,\u201d said the Emperor, \u201cit is promised.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille was not able to restrain a joyous movement hardly in keeping.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYou can ring now, Sire.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      And the Tsar rang.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      The reporter passed into a little salon, where he found the Marshal,\r\n\r\n      Koupriane and Matrena Petrovna, who was \u201cin a state.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      She threw a suspicious glance at Rouletabille, who was not treated this\r\n\r\n      morning as the dear little domovoi-doukh. She permitted herself to be\r\n\r\n      conducted, already trembling, before the Emperor.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWhat happened?\u201d asked Koupriane agitatedly.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cIt so happened, my dear Monsieur Koupriane, that I have the pardon of the\r\n\r\n      Emperor for all the crimes you have charged against me, and that I wish to\r\n\r\n      shake hands before I go, without any rancor. Monsieur Koupriane, the\r\n\r\n      Emperor will tell you himself that General Trebassof is saved, and that\r\n\r\n      his life will never be in danger any more. Do you know what follows? It\r\n\r\n      follows that you must at once set Matiew free, whom I have taken, if you\r\n\r\n      remember, under my protection. Tell him that he is going to make his way\r\n\r\n      in France. I will find him a place on condition that he forgets certain\r\n\r\n      lashes.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cSuch a promise! Such an attitude toward me!\u201d cried Koupriane. \u201cBut I will\r\n\r\n      wait for the Emperor to tell me all these fine things. And your Natacha,\r\n\r\n      what do you do with her?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWe release her also, monsieur. Natacha never has been the monster that\r\n\r\n      you think.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cHow can you say that? Someone at least is guilty.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThere are two guilty. The first, Monsieur le Marechal.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cWhat!\u201d cried the Marshal.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMonsieur le Marechal, who had the imprudence to bring such dangerous\r\n\r\n      grapes to the datcha des Iles, and\u2014and\u2014\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cAnd the other?\u201d asked Koupriane, more and more anxiously.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cListen there,\u201d said Rouletabille, pointing toward the Emperor\u2019s cabinet.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      The sound of tears and sobs reached them. The grief and the remorse of\r\n\r\n      Matrena Petrovna passed the walls of the cabinet. Koupriane was completely\r\n\r\n      disconcerted.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Suddenly the Emperor appeared. He was in a state of exaltation such as had\r\n\r\n      never been known in him. Koupriane, dismayed, drew back.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMonsieur,\u201d said the Tsar to him, \u201cI require that Natacha Feodorovna be\r\n\r\n      here within the next two hours, and that she be conducted with the honors\r\n\r\n      due to her rank. Natacha is innocent, and we must make reparation to her.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      Then, turning toward Rouletabille:\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI have learned what she knows and what she owes to you\u2014we owe to\r\n\r\n      you, my young friend.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      The Tsar said \u201cmy young friend.\u201d Rouletabille, at this last moment before\r\n\r\n      his departure, spoke Russian?\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThen she knows nothing, Sire. That is better, Sire, because Your Majesty\r\n\r\n      and me, we must forget right from to-day that we know anything.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cYou are right,\u201d said the Tsar thoughtfully. \u201cBut, my friend, what am I to\r\n\r\n      do for you?\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cSire, one favor. Do not let me miss the train at 10:55.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      And he threw himself on his knees.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cRemain on your knees, my friend. You are ready, thus. Monsieur le\r\n\r\n      Marechal will prepare at once a brevet, which I will immediately sign.\r\n\r\n      Meantime, Monsieur le Marechal, find me, in my own closet, one of my St.\r\n\r\n      Anne\u2019s collars.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      And it was thus that Joseph Rouletabille, of \u201cL\u2019Epoque,\u201d was created\r\n\r\n      officer of St. Anne of Russia by the Emperor himself, who gave him the\r\n\r\n      accolade.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cThey combine the whole course of time in this country,\u201d thought\r\n\r\n      Rouletabille, pressing his hand to his eyes to hold back the tears.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      For the train at 10:55 everybody had crowded at Tsarskoie-Coelo station.\r\n\r\n      Among those who had come from St. Petersburg to press the young reporter\u2019s\r\n\r\n      hand when they learned of his impending departure were Ivan Petrovitch,\r\n\r\n      the jolly Councilor of the Emperor, and Athanase Georgevitch, the lively\r\n\r\n      advocate so well known for his famous exploits with knife and fork. They\r\n\r\n      had come naturally with all their bandages and dressings, which made them\r\n\r\n      look like glorious ruins. They brought the greetings of Feodor\r\n\r\n      Feodorovitch, who still had a little fever, and of Thaddeus Tchitchnikoff,\r\n\r\n      the Lithuanian, who had both legs broken.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Even after he was in his compartment Rouletabille had to drink his last\r\n\r\n      drink of champagne. When nothing remained in the bottle and everyone had\r\n\r\n      embraced and re-embraced him, as the train did not start quite yet,\r\n\r\n      Athanase Georgevitch opened a second \u201clast\u201d bottle. It was then that\r\n\r\n      Monsieur le Grand Marechal arrived, out of breath. They invited him to\r\n\r\n      drink, and he accepted. But he had need to speak to Rouletabille in\r\n\r\n      private, and he drew the reporter, after excuses, out into the corridor.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cIt is the Emperor himself who has sent me,\u201d said the high dignitary with\r\n\r\n      emotion. \u201cHe has sent me about the eider downs. You forgot to explain the\r\n\r\n      eider downs to him.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cNiet!\u201d replied Rouletabille, laughing. \u201cThat is nothing. Nitchevo! His\r\n\r\n      Majesty\u2019s eider downs are of the finest eider, as one of the feathers that\r\n\r\n      you have shown me demonstrates. Well, open them now. They are a cheap\r\n\r\n      imitation, as the second feather proves. The return of the false eider\r\n\r\n      downs, before evening, proves then that they hoped the substitution would\r\n\r\n      pass undetected. That is all. Caracho! Collapse of the hoax. Your health!\r\n\r\n      Vive le Tsar!\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cCaracho! Caracho!\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      The locomotive was puffing when a couple were seen running, a man and a\r\n\r\n      woman. It was Monsieur and Madame Gounsovski.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Gounsovski stood on the running-board.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cMadame Gounsovski has insisted upon shaking hands. You are very\r\n\r\n      congenial.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cCompliments, madame.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cTell me, young man, you did wrong to fail for dinner at my house\r\n\r\n      yesterday.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cI would have certainly escaped a disagreeable little journey into\r\n\r\n      Finland. I do not regret it, monsieur.\u201d\r\n\r\n     \r\n\r\n\r\n      The train trembled and moved. They cried, \u201cVive la France! Vive la Russe!\u201d\r\n\r\n       Athanase Georgevitch wept. Matrena Petrovna, at a window of the station,\r\n\r\n      whither she had timidly retired, waved a handkerchief to the little\r\n\r\n      domovoi-doukh, who had made her see everything in the right light, and\r\n\r\n      whom she did not dare to embrace after the terrible affair of the false\r\n\r\n      poison and the Tsar\u2019s anger.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      The reporter threw her a respectful kiss.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      As he said to Gounsovski, there was nothing to be regretted.\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      All the same, as the train took its way toward the frontier, Rouletabille\r\n\r\n      threw himself back on the cushions, and said:\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      \u201cOuf!\u201d
PARMENIDES\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      By Plato\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n      Translated by Benjamin Jowett\r\n    \r\n\r\n \r\n\r\n\r\n \r\n\r\n\r\n      Contents\r\n    \r\n\r\n\r\n INTRODUCTION AND ANALYSIS. \r\n\r\n\r\n PARMENIDES \r\n\r\n\r\n \r\n\r\n\r\n  \r\n \r\n\r\n\r\n      INTRODUCTION AND ANALYSIS.\r\n    \r\n\r\n      The awe with which Plato regarded the character of 'the great' Parmenides\r\n      has extended to the dialogue which he calls by his name. None of the\r\n      writings of Plato have been more copiously illustrated, both in ancient\r\n      and modern times, and in none of them have the interpreters been more at\r\n      variance with one another. Nor is this surprising. For the Parmenides is\r\n      more fragmentary and isolated than any other dialogue, and the design of\r\n      the writer is not expressly stated. The date is uncertain; the relation to\r\n      the other writings of Plato is also uncertain; the connexion between the\r\n      two parts is at first sight extremely obscure; and in the latter of the\r\n      two we are left in doubt as to whether Plato is speaking his own\r\n      sentiments by the lips of Parmenides, and overthrowing him out of his own\r\n      mouth, or whether he is propounding consequences which would have been\r\n      admitted by Zeno and Parmenides themselves. The contradictions which\r\n      follow from the hypotheses of the one and many have been regarded by some\r\n      as transcendental mysteries; by others as a mere illustration, taken at\r\n      random, of a new method. They seem to have been inspired by a sort of\r\n      dialectical frenzy, such as may be supposed to have prevailed in the\r\n      Megarian School (compare Cratylus, etc.). The criticism on his own\r\n      doctrine of Ideas has also been considered, not as a real criticism, but\r\n      as an exuberance of the metaphysical imagination which enabled Plato to go\r\n      beyond himself. To the latter part of the dialogue we may certainly apply\r\n      the words in which he himself describes the earlier philosophers in the\r\n      Sophist: 'They went on their way rather regardless of whether we\r\n      understood them or not.'\r\n    \r\n\r\n      The Parmenides in point of style is one of the best of the Platonic\r\n      writings; the first portion of the dialogue is in no way defective in ease\r\n      and grace and dramatic interest; nor in the second part, where there was\r\n      no room for such qualities, is there any want of clearness or precision.\r\n      The latter half is an exquisite mosaic, of which the small pieces are with\r\n      the utmost fineness and regularity adapted to one another. Like the\r\n      Protagoras, Phaedo, and others, the whole is a narrated dialogue,\r\n      combining with the mere recital of the words spoken, the observations of\r\n      the reciter on the effect produced by them. Thus we are informed by him\r\n      that Zeno and Parmenides were not altogether pleased at the request of\r\n      Socrates that they would examine into the nature of the one and many in\r\n      the sphere of Ideas, although they received his suggestion with approving\r\n      smiles. And we are glad to be told that Parmenides was 'aged but\r\n      well-favoured,' and that Zeno was 'very good-looking'; also that\r\n      Parmenides affected to decline the great argument, on which, as Zeno knew\r\n      from experience, he was not unwilling to enter. The character of Antiphon,\r\n      the half-brother of Plato, who had once been inclined to philosophy, but\r\n      has now shown the hereditary disposition for horses, is very naturally\r\n      described. He is the sole depositary of the famous dialogue; but, although\r\n      he receives the strangers like a courteous gentleman, he is impatient of\r\n      the trouble of reciting it. As they enter, he has been giving orders to a\r\n      bridle-maker; by this slight touch Plato verifies the previous description\r\n      of him. After a little persuasion he is induced to favour the\r\n      Clazomenians, who come from a distance, with a rehearsal. Respecting the\r\n      visit of Zeno and Parmenides to Athens, we may observe\u2014first, that\r\n      such a visit is consistent with dates, and may possibly have occurred;\r\n      secondly, that Plato is very likely to have invented the meeting ('You,\r\n      Socrates, can easily invent Egyptian tales or anything else,' Phaedrus);\r\n      thirdly, that no reliance can be placed on the circumstance as determining\r\n      the date of Parmenides and Zeno; fourthly, that the same occasion appears\r\n      to be referred to by Plato in two other places (Theaet., Soph.).\r\n    \r\n\r\n      Many interpreters have regarded the Parmenides as a 'reductio ad absurdum'\r\n      of the Eleatic philosophy. But would Plato have been likely to place this\r\n      in the mouth of the great Parmenides himself, who appeared to him, in\r\n      Homeric language, to be 'venerable and awful,' and to have a 'glorious\r\n      depth of mind'? (Theaet.). It may be admitted that he has ascribed to an\r\n      Eleatic stranger in the Sophist opinions which went beyond the doctrines\r\n      of the Eleatics. But the Eleatic stranger expressly criticises the\r\n      doctrines in which he had been brought up; he admits that he is going to\r\n      'lay hands on his father Parmenides.' Nothing of this kind is said of Zeno\r\n      and Parmenides. How then, without a word of explanation, could Plato\r\n      assign to them the refutation of their own tenets?\r\n    \r\n\r\n      The conclusion at which we must arrive is that the Parmenides is not a\r\n      refutation of the Eleatic philosophy. Nor would such an explanation afford\r\n      any satisfactory connexion of the first and second parts of the dialogue.\r\n      And it is quite inconsistent with Plato's own relation to the Eleatics.\r\n      For of all the pre-Socratic philosophers, he speaks of them with the\r\n      greatest respect. But he could hardly have passed upon them a more\r\n      unmeaning slight than to ascribe to their great master tenets the reverse\r\n      of those which he actually held.\r\n    \r\n\r\n      Two preliminary remarks may be made. First, that whatever latitude we may\r\n      allow to Plato in bringing together by a 'tour de force,' as in the\r\n      Phaedrus, dissimilar themes, yet he always in some way seeks to find a\r\n      connexion for them. Many threads join together in one the love and\r\n      dialectic of the Phaedrus. We cannot conceive that the great artist would\r\n      place in juxtaposition two absolutely divided and incoherent subjects. And\r\n      hence we are led to make a second remark: viz. that no explanation of the\r\n      Parmenides can be satisfactory which does not indicate the connexion of\r\n      the first and second parts. To suppose that Plato would first go out of\r\n      his way to make Parmenides attack the Platonic Ideas, and then proceed to\r\n      a similar but more fatal assault on his own doctrine of Being, appears to\r\n      be the height of absurdity.\r\n    \r\n\r\n      Perhaps there is no passage in Plato showing greater metaphysical power\r\n      than that in which he assails his own theory of Ideas. The arguments are\r\n      nearly, if not quite, those of Aristotle; they are the objections which\r\n      naturally occur to a modern student of philosophy. Many persons will be\r\n      surprised to find Plato criticizing the very conceptions which have been\r\n      supposed in after ages to be peculiarly characteristic of him. How can he\r\n      have placed himself so completely without them? How can he have ever\r\n      persisted in them after seeing the fatal objections which might be urged\r\n      against them? The consideration of this difficulty has led a recent critic\r\n      (Ueberweg), who in general accepts the authorised canon of the Platonic\r\n      writings, to condemn the Parmenides as spurious. The accidental want of\r\n      external evidence, at first sight, seems to favour this opinion.\r\n    \r\n\r\n      In answer, it might be sufficient to say, that no ancient writing of equal\r\n      length and excellence is known to be spurious. Nor is the silence of\r\n      Aristotle to be hastily assumed; there is at least a doubt whether his use\r\n      of the same arguments does not involve the inference that he knew the\r\n      work. And, if the Parmenides is spurious, like Ueberweg, we are led on\r\n      further than we originally intended, to pass a similar condemnation on the\r\n      Theaetetus and Sophist, and therefore on the Politicus (compare Theaet.,\r\n      Soph.). But the objection is in reality fanciful, and rests on the\r\n      assumption that the doctrine of the Ideas was held by Plato throughout his\r\n      life in the same form. For the truth is, that the Platonic Ideas were in\r\n      constant process of growth and transmutation; sometimes veiled in poetry\r\n      and mythology, then again emerging as fixed Ideas, in some passages\r\n      regarded as absolute and eternal, and in others as relative to the human\r\n      mind, existing in and derived from external objects as well as\r\n      transcending them. The anamnesis of the Ideas is chiefly insisted upon in\r\n      the mythical portions of the dialogues, and really occupies a very small\r\n      space in the entire works of Plato. Their transcendental existence is not\r\n      asserted, and is therefore implicitly denied in the Philebus; different\r\n      forms are ascribed to them in the Republic, and they are mentioned in the\r\n      Theaetetus, the Sophist, the Politicus, and the Laws, much as Universals\r\n      would be spoken of in modern books. Indeed, there are very faint traces of\r\n      the transcendental doctrine of Ideas, that is, of their existence apart\r\n      from the mind, in any of Plato's writings, with the exception of the Meno,\r\n      the Phaedrus, the Phaedo, and in portions of the Republic. The stereotyped\r\n      form which Aristotle has given to them is not found in Plato (compare\r\n      Essay on the Platonic Ideas in the Introduction to the Meno.)\r\n    \r\n\r\n      The full discussion of this subject involves a comprehensive survey of the\r\n      philosophy of Plato, which would be out of place here. But, without\r\n      digressing further from the immediate subject of the Parmenides, we may\r\n      remark that Plato is quite serious in his objections to his own doctrines:\r\n      nor does Socrates attempt to offer any answer to them. The perplexities\r\n      which surround the one and many in the sphere of the Ideas are also\r\n      alluded to in the Philebus, and no answer is given to them. Nor have they\r\n      ever been answered, nor can they be answered by any one else who separates\r\n      the phenomenal from the real. To suppose that Plato, at a later period of\r\n      his life, reached a point of view from which he was able to answer them,\r\n      is a groundless assumption. The real progress of Plato's own mind has been\r\n      partly concealed from us by the dogmatic statements of Aristotle, and also\r\n      by the degeneracy of his own followers, with whom a doctrine of numbers\r\n      quickly superseded Ideas.\r\n    \r\n\r\n      As a preparation for answering some of the difficulties which have been\r\n      suggested, we may begin by sketching the first portion of the dialogue:\u2014\r\n    \r\n\r\n      Cephalus, of Clazomenae in Ionia, the birthplace of Anaxagoras, a citizen\r\n      of no mean city in the history of philosophy, who is the narrator of the\r\n      dialogue, describes himself as meeting Adeimantus and Glaucon in the Agora\r\n      at Athens. 'Welcome, Cephalus: can we do anything for you in Athens?'\r\n      'Why, yes: I came to ask a favour of you. First, tell me your\r\n      half-brother's name, which I have forgotten\u2014he was a mere child when\r\n      I was last here;\u2014I know his father's, which is Pyrilampes.' 'Yes,\r\n      and the name of our brother is Antiphon. But why do you ask?' 'Let me\r\n      introduce to you some countrymen of mine, who are lovers of philosophy;\r\n      they have heard that Antiphon remembers a conversation of Socrates with\r\n      Parmenides and Zeno, of which the report came to him from Pythodorus,\r\n      Zeno's friend.' 'That is quite true.' 'And can they hear the dialogue?'\r\n      'Nothing easier; in the days of his youth he made a careful study of the\r\n      piece; at present, his thoughts have another direction: he takes after his\r\n      grandfather, and has given up philosophy for horses.'\r\n    \r\n\r\n      'We went to look for him, and found him giving instructions to a worker in\r\n      brass about a bridle. When he had done with him, and had learned from his\r\n      brothers the purpose of our visit, he saluted me as an old acquaintance,\r\n      and we asked him to repeat the dialogue. At first, he complained of the\r\n      trouble, but he soon consented. He told us that Pythodorus had described\r\n      to him the appearance of Parmenides and Zeno; they had come to Athens at\r\n      the great Panathenaea, the former being at the time about sixty-five years\r\n      old, aged but well-favoured\u2014Zeno, who was said to have been beloved\r\n      of Parmenides in the days of his youth, about forty, and very\r\n      good-looking:\u2014that they lodged with Pythodorus at the Ceramicus\r\n      outside the wall, whither Socrates, then a very young man, came to see\r\n      them: Zeno was reading one of his theses, which he had nearly finished,\r\n      when Pythodorus entered with Parmenides and Aristoteles, who was\r\n      afterwards one of the Thirty. When the recitation was completed, Socrates\r\n      requested that the first thesis of the treatise might be read again.'\r\n    \r\n\r\n      'You mean, Zeno,' said Socrates, 'to argue that being, if it is many, must\r\n      be both like and unlike, which is a contradiction; and each division of\r\n      your argument is intended to elicit a similar absurdity, which may be\r\n      supposed to follow from the assumption that being is many.' 'Such is my\r\n      meaning.' 'I see,' said Socrates, turning to Parmenides, 'that Zeno is\r\n      your second self in his writings too; you prove admirably that the all is\r\n      one: he gives proofs no less convincing that the many are nought. To\r\n      deceive the world by saying the same thing in entirely different forms, is\r\n      a strain of art beyond most of us.' 'Yes, Socrates,' said Zeno; 'but\r\n      though you are as keen as a Spartan hound, you do not quite catch the\r\n      motive of the piece, which was only intended to protect Parmenides against\r\n      ridicule by showing that the hypothesis of the existence of the many\r\n      involved greater absurdities than the hypothesis of the one. The book was\r\n      a youthful composition of mine, which was stolen from me, and therefore I\r\n      had no choice about the publication.' 'I quite believe you,' said\r\n      Socrates; 'but will you answer me a question? I should like to know,\r\n      whether you would assume an idea of likeness in the abstract, which is the\r\n      contradictory of unlikeness in the abstract, by participation in either or\r\n      both of which things are like or unlike or partly both. For the same\r\n      things may very well partake of like and unlike in the concrete, though\r\n      like and unlike in the abstract are irreconcilable. Nor does there appear\r\n      to me to be any absurdity in maintaining that the same things may partake\r\n      of the one and many, though I should be indeed surprised to hear that the\r\n      absolute one is also many. For example, I, being many, that is to say,\r\n      having many parts or members, am yet also one, and partake of the one,\r\n      being one of seven who are here present (compare Philebus). This is not an\r\n      absurdity, but a truism. But I should be amazed if there were a similar\r\n      entanglement in the nature of the ideas themselves, nor can I believe that\r\n      one and many, like and unlike, rest and motion, in the abstract, are\r\n      capable either of admixture or of separation.'\r\n    \r\n\r\n      Pythodorus said that in his opinion Parmenides and Zeno were not very well\r\n      pleased at the questions which were raised; nevertheless, they looked at\r\n      one another and smiled in seeming delight and admiration of Socrates.\r\n      'Tell me,' said Parmenides, 'do you think that the abstract ideas of\r\n      likeness, unity, and the rest, exist apart from individuals which partake\r\n      of them? and is this your own distinction?' 'I think that there are such\r\n      ideas.' 'And would you make abstract ideas of the just, the beautiful, the\r\n      good?' 'Yes,' he said. 'And of human beings like ourselves, of water,\r\n      fire, and the like?' 'I am not certain.' 'And would you be undecided also\r\n      about ideas of which the mention will, perhaps, appear laughable: of hair,\r\n      mud, filth, and other things which are base and vile?' 'No, Parmenides;\r\n      visible things like these are, as I believe, only what they appear to be:\r\n      though I am sometimes disposed to imagine that there is nothing without an\r\n      idea; but I repress any such notion, from a fear of falling into an abyss\r\n      of nonsense.' 'You are young, Socrates, and therefore naturally regard the\r\n      opinions of men; the time will come when philosophy will have a firmer\r\n      hold of you, and you will not despise even the meanest things. But tell\r\n      me, is your meaning that things become like by partaking of likeness,\r\n      great by partaking of greatness, just and beautiful by partaking of\r\n      justice and beauty, and so of other ideas?' 'Yes, that is my meaning.'\r\n      'And do you suppose the individual to partake of the whole, or of the\r\n      part?' 'Why not of the whole?' said Socrates. 'Because,' said Parmenides,\r\n      'in that case the whole, which is one, will become many.' 'Nay,' said\r\n      Socrates, 'the whole may be like the day, which is one and in many places:\r\n      in this way the ideas may be one and also many.' 'In the same sort of\r\n      way,' said Parmenides, 'as a sail, which is one, may be a cover to many\u2014that\r\n      is your meaning?' 'Yes.' 'And would you say that each man is covered by\r\n      the whole sail, or by a part only?' 'By a part.' 'Then the ideas have\r\n      parts, and the objects partake of a part of them only?' 'That seems to\r\n      follow.' 'And would you like to say that the ideas are really divisible\r\n      and yet remain one?' 'Certainly not.' 'Would you venture to affirm that\r\n      great objects have a portion only of greatness transferred to them; or\r\n      that small or equal objects are small or equal because they are only\r\n      portions of smallness or equality?' 'Impossible.' 'But how can individuals\r\n      participate in ideas, except in the ways which I have mentioned?' 'That is\r\n      not an easy question to answer.' 'I should imagine the conception of ideas\r\n      to arise as follows: you see great objects pervaded by a common form or\r\n      idea of greatness, which you abstract.' 'That is quite true.' 'And\r\n      supposing you embrace in one view the idea of greatness thus gained and\r\n      the individuals which it comprises, a further idea of greatness arises,\r\n      which makes both great; and this may go on to infinity.' Socrates replies\r\n      that the ideas may be thoughts in the mind only; in this case, the\r\n      consequence would no longer follow. 'But must not the thought be of\r\n      something which is the same in all and is the idea? And if the world\r\n      partakes in the ideas, and the ideas are thoughts, must not all things\r\n      think? Or can thought be without thought?' 'I acknowledge the\r\n      unmeaningness of this,' says Socrates, 'and would rather have recourse to\r\n      the explanation that the ideas are types in nature, and that other things\r\n      partake of them by becoming like them.' 'But to become like them is to be\r\n      comprehended in the same idea; and the likeness of the idea and the\r\n      individuals implies another idea of likeness, and another without end.'\r\n      'Quite true.' 'The theory, then, of participation by likeness has to be\r\n      given up. You have hardly yet, Socrates, found out the real difficulty of\r\n      maintaining abstract ideas.' 'What difficulty?' 'The greatest of all\r\n      perhaps is this: an opponent will argue that the ideas are not within the\r\n      range of human knowledge; and you cannot disprove the assertion without a\r\n      long and laborious demonstration, which he may be unable or unwilling to\r\n      follow. In the first place, neither you nor any one who maintains the\r\n      existence of absolute ideas will affirm that they are subjective.' 'That\r\n      would be a contradiction.' 'True; and therefore any relation in these\r\n      ideas is a relation which concerns themselves only; and the objects which\r\n      are named after them, are relative to one another only, and have nothing\r\n      to do with the ideas themselves.' 'How do you mean?' said Socrates. 'I may\r\n      illustrate my meaning in this way: one of us has a slave; and the idea of\r\n      a slave in the abstract is relative to the idea of a master in the\r\n      abstract; this correspondence of ideas, however, has nothing to do with\r\n      the particular relation of our slave to us.\u2014Do you see my meaning?'\r\n      'Perfectly.' 'And absolute knowledge in the same way corresponds to\r\n      absolute truth and being, and particular knowledge to particular truth and\r\n      being.' Clearly.' 'And there is a subjective knowledge which is of\r\n      subjective truth, having many kinds, general and particular. But the ideas\r\n      themselves are not subjective, and therefore are not within our ken.'\r\n      'They are not.' 'Then the beautiful and the good in their own nature are\r\n      unknown to us?' 'It would seem so.' 'There is a worse consequence yet.'\r\n      'What is that?' 'I think we must admit that absolute knowledge is the most\r\n      exact knowledge, which we must therefore attribute to God. But then see\r\n      what follows: God, having this exact knowledge, can have no knowledge of\r\n      human things, as we have divided the two spheres, and forbidden any\r\n      passing from one to the other:\u2014the gods have knowledge and authority\r\n      in their world only, as we have in ours.' 'Yet, surely, to deprive God of\r\n      knowledge is monstrous.'\u2014'These are some of the difficulties which\r\n      are involved in the assumption of absolute ideas; the learner will find\r\n      them nearly impossible to understand, and the teacher who has to impart\r\n      them will require superhuman ability; there will always be a suspicion,\r\n      either that they have no existence, or are beyond human knowledge.' 'There\r\n      I agree with you,' said Socrates. 'Yet if these difficulties induce you to\r\n      give up universal ideas, what becomes of the mind? and where are the\r\n      reasoning and reflecting powers? philosophy is at an end.' 'I certainly do\r\n      not see my way.' 'I think,' said Parmenides, 'that this arises out of your\r\n      attempting to define abstractions, such as the good and the beautiful and\r\n      the just, before you have had sufficient previous training; I noticed your\r\n      deficiency when you were talking with Aristoteles, the day before\r\n      yesterday. Your enthusiasm is a wonderful gift; but I fear that unless you\r\n      discipline yourself by dialectic while you are young, truth will elude\r\n      your grasp.' 'And what kind of discipline would you recommend?' 'The\r\n      training which you heard Zeno practising; at the same time, I admire your\r\n      saying to him that you did not care to consider the difficulty in\r\n      reference to visible objects, but only in relation to ideas.' 'Yes;\r\n      because I think that in visible objects you may easily show any number of\r\n      inconsistent consequences.' 'Yes; and you should consider, not only the\r\n      consequences which follow from a given hypothesis, but the consequences\r\n      also which follow from the denial of the hypothesis. For example, what\r\n      follows from the assumption of the existence of the many, and the\r\n      counter-argument of what follows from the denial of the existence of the\r\n      many: and similarly of likeness and unlikeness, motion, rest, generation,\r\n      corruption, being and not being. And the consequences must include\r\n      consequences to the things supposed and to other things, in themselves and\r\n      in relation to one another, to individuals whom you select, to the many,\r\n      and to the all; these must be drawn out both on the affirmative and on the\r\n      negative hypothesis,\u2014that is, if you are to train yourself perfectly\r\n      to the intelligence of the truth.' 'What you are suggesting seems to be a\r\n      tremendous process, and one of which I do not quite understand the\r\n      nature,' said Socrates; 'will you give me an example?' 'You must not\r\n      impose such a task on a man of my years,' said Parmenides. 'Then will you,\r\n      Zeno?' 'Let us rather,' said Zeno, with a smile, 'ask Parmenides, for the\r\n      undertaking is a serious one, as he truly says; nor could I urge him to\r\n      make the attempt, except in a select audience of persons who will\r\n      understand him.' The whole party joined in the request.\r\n    \r\n\r\n      Here we have, first of all, an unmistakable attack made by the youthful\r\n      Socrates on the paradoxes of Zeno. He perfectly understands their drift,\r\n      and Zeno himself is supposed to admit this. But they appear to him, as he\r\n      says in the Philebus also, to be rather truisms than paradoxes. For every\r\n      one must acknowledge the obvious fact, that the body being one has many\r\n      members, and that, in a thousand ways, the like partakes of the unlike,\r\n      the many of the one. The real difficulty begins with the relations of\r\n      ideas in themselves, whether of the one and many, or of any other ideas,\r\n      to one another and to the mind. But this was a problem which the Eleatic\r\n      philosophers had never considered; their thoughts had not gone beyond the\r\n      contradictions of matter, motion, space, and the like.\r\n    \r\n\r\n      It was no wonder that Parmenides and Zeno should hear the novel\r\n      speculations of Socrates with mixed feelings of admiration and\r\n      displeasure. He was going out of the received circle of disputation into a\r\n      region in which they could hardly follow him. From the crude idea of Being\r\n      in the abstract, he was about to proceed to universals or general notions.\r\n      There is no contradiction in material things partaking of the ideas of one\r\n      and many; neither is there any contradiction in the ideas of one and many,\r\n      like and unlike, in themselves. But the contradiction arises when we\r\n      attempt to conceive ideas in their connexion, or to ascertain their\r\n      relation to phenomena. Still he affirms the existence of such ideas; and\r\n      this is the position which is now in turn submitted to the criticisms of\r\n      Parmenides.\r\n    \r\n\r\n      To appreciate truly the character of these criticisms, we must remember\r\n      the place held by Parmenides in the history of Greek philosophy. He is the\r\n      founder of idealism, and also of dialectic, or, in modern phraseology, of\r\n      metaphysics and logic (Theaet., Soph.). Like Plato, he is struggling after\r\n      something wider and deeper than satisfied the contemporary Pythagoreans.\r\n      And Plato with a true instinct recognizes him as his spiritual father,\r\n      whom he 'revered and honoured more than all other philosophers together.'\r\n      He may be supposed to have thought more than he said, or was able to\r\n      express. And, although he could not, as a matter of fact, have criticized\r\n      the ideas of Plato without an anachronism, the criticism is appropriately\r\n      placed in the mouth of the founder of the ideal philosophy.\r\n    \r\n\r\n      There was probably a time in the life of Plato when the ethical teaching\r\n      of Socrates came into conflict with the metaphysical theories of the\r\n      earlier philosophers, and he sought to supplement the one by the other.\r\n      The older philosophers were great and awful; and they had the charm of\r\n      antiquity. Something which found a response in his own mind seemed to have\r\n      been lost as well as gained in the Socratic dialectic. He felt no\r\n      incongruity in the veteran Parmenides correcting the youthful Socrates.\r\n      Two points in his criticism are especially deserving of notice. First of\r\n      all, Parmenides tries him by the test of consistency. Socrates is willing\r\n      to assume ideas or principles of the just, the beautiful, the good, and to\r\n      extend them to man (compare Phaedo); but he is reluctant to admit that\r\n      there are general ideas of hair, mud, filth, etc. There is an ethical\r\n      universal or idea, but is there also a universal of physics?\u2014of the\r\n      meanest things in the world as well as of the greatest? Parmenides rebukes\r\n      this want of consistency in Socrates, which he attributes to his youth. As\r\n      he grows older, philosophy will take a firmer hold of him, and then he\r\n      will despise neither great things nor small, and he will think less of the\r\n      opinions of mankind (compare Soph.). Here is lightly touched one of the\r\n      most familiar principles of modern philosophy, that in the meanest\r\n      operations of nature, as well as in the noblest, in mud and filth, as well\r\n      as in the sun and stars, great truths are contained. At the same time, we\r\n      may note also the transition in the mind of Plato, to which Aristotle\r\n      alludes (Met.), when, as he says, he transferred the Socratic universal of\r\n      ethics to the whole of nature.\r\n    \r\n\r\n      The other criticism of Parmenides on Socrates attributes to him a want of\r\n      practice in dialectic. He has observed this deficiency in him when talking\r\n      to Aristoteles on a previous occasion. Plato seems to imply that there was\r\n      something more in the dialectic of Zeno than in the mere interrogation of\r\n      Socrates. Here, again, he may perhaps be describing the process which his\r\n      own mind went through when he first became more intimately acquainted,\r\n      whether at Megara or elsewhere, with the Eleatic and Megarian\r\n      philosophers. Still, Parmenides does not deny to Socrates the credit of\r\n      having gone beyond them in seeking to apply the paradoxes of Zeno to\r\n      ideas; and this is the application which he himself makes of them in the\r\n      latter part of the dialogue. He then proceeds to explain to him the sort\r\n      of mental gymnastic which he should practise. He should consider not only\r\n      what would follow from a given hypothesis, but what would follow from the\r\n      denial of it, to that which is the subject of the hypothesis, and to all\r\n      other things. There is no trace in the Memorabilia of Xenophon of any such\r\n      method being attributed to Socrates; nor is the dialectic here spoken of\r\n      that 'favourite method' of proceeding by regular divisions, which is\r\n      described in the Phaedrus and Philebus, and of which examples are given in\r\n      the Politicus and in the Sophist. It is expressly spoken of as the method\r\n      which Socrates had heard Zeno practise in the days of his youth (compare\r\n      Soph.).\r\n    \r\n\r\n      The discussion of Socrates with Parmenides is one of the most remarkable\r\n      passages in Plato. Few writers have ever been able to anticipate 'the\r\n      criticism of the morrow' on their favourite notions. But Plato may here be\r\n      said to anticipate the judgment not only of the morrow, but of all\r\n      after-ages on the Platonic Ideas. For in some points he touches questions\r\n      which have not yet received their solution in modern philosophy.\r\n    \r\n\r\n      The first difficulty which Parmenides raises respecting the Platonic ideas\r\n      relates to the manner in which individuals are connected with them. Do\r\n      they participate in the ideas, or do they merely resemble them? Parmenides\r\n      shows that objections may be urged against either of these modes of\r\n      conceiving the connection. Things are little by partaking of littleness,\r\n      great by partaking of greatness, and the like. But they cannot partake of\r\n      a part of greatness, for that will not make them great, etc.; nor can each\r\n      object monopolise the whole. The only answer to this is, that 'partaking'\r\n      is a figure of speech, really corresponding to the processes which a later\r\n      logic designates by the terms 'abstraction' and 'generalization.' When we\r\n      have described accurately the methods or forms which the mind employs, we\r\n      cannot further criticize them; at least we can only criticize them with\r\n      reference to their fitness as instruments of thought to express facts.\r\n    \r\n\r\n      Socrates attempts to support his view of the ideas by the parallel of the\r\n      day, which is one and in many places; but he is easily driven from his\r\n      position by a counter illustration of Parmenides, who compares the idea of\r\n      greatness to a sail. He truly explains to Socrates that he has attained\r\n      the conception of ideas by a process of generalization. At the same time,\r\n      he points out a difficulty, which appears to be involved\u2014viz. that\r\n      the process of generalization will go on to infinity. Socrates meets the\r\n      supposed difficulty by a flash of light, which is indeed the true answer\r\n      'that the ideas are in our minds only.' Neither realism is the truth, nor\r\n      nominalism is the truth, but conceptualism; and conceptualism or any other\r\n      psychological theory falls very far short of the infinite subtlety of\r\n      language and thought.\r\n    \r\n\r\n      But the realism of ancient philosophy will not admit of this answer, which\r\n      is repelled by Parmenides with another truth or half-truth of later\r\n      philosophy, 'Every subject or subjective must have an object.' Here is the\r\n      great though unconscious truth (shall we say?) or error, which underlay\r\n      the early Greek philosophy. 'Ideas must have a real existence;' they are\r\n      not mere forms or opinions, which may be changed arbitrarily by\r\n      individuals. But the early Greek philosopher never clearly saw that true\r\n      ideas were only universal facts, and that there might be error in\r\n      universals as well as in particulars.\r\n    \r\n\r\n      Socrates makes one more attempt to defend the Platonic Ideas by\r\n      representing them as paradigms; this is again answered by the 'argumentum\r\n      ad infinitum.' We may remark, in passing, that the process which is thus\r\n      described has no real existence. The mind, after having obtained a general\r\n      idea, does not really go on to form another which includes that, and all\r\n      the individuals contained under it, and another and another without end.\r\n      The difficulty belongs in fact to the Megarian age of philosophy, and is\r\n      due to their illogical logic, and to the general ignorance of the ancients\r\n      respecting the part played by language in the process of thought. No such\r\n      perplexity could ever trouble a modern metaphysician, any more than the\r\n      fallacy of 'calvus' or 'acervus,' or of 'Achilles and the tortoise.'
